div.head: THE PREFACE TO the Reader. Wherein Mr. FITZHERBERTS PREFACE is confuted, the matter which WIDDRINGTON handleth, and the manner how he proceedeth therein, is declared, and his doctrine proued to be truely probable, and neither preiudiciall to his MAIESTIES Å¿eruice, nor to the ConÅ¿ciences of Catholikes.
div.p:
1. IT is not vnknowne to thee, Courteous Reader, the great controuerÅ¿ie hath been of late yeares, eÅ¿pecially among vs EngliÅ¿h Catholikes, concerning the new oath of Allegiance, which his Maiestie by Act of Parliament hath ordained to make triall how his Catholike Subiects Å¿tand affected towards him in point of there loyaltie, and due obedience. For although his HolineÅ¿Å¿e, by the inÅ¿tigation and importunitie no doubt of others, hath by three Å¿euerall Breues declared the Å¿aid oath to be vnlawfull,
and to containe in it many things cleerely repugnant to faith and Å¿aluation, and many learned men, eÅ¿pecially IeÅ¿uites, as Card. Bellarmine Fa: Gretzer, LeÅ¿Å¿ius, Becanus, and now laÅ¿tly Suarez, haue by publike writings endeauoured to conuince the Å¿ame, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ince that Mr. George Blackwell then Archpraesbiter, and many other learned PrieÅ¿ts did from the very firÅ¿t publiÅ¿hing of this oath defend it to bee lawfull, and not to containe in it any thing, which either expreÅ¿Å¿ely, or couertly is contrarie to Catholike faith or Å¿aluation, the Å¿aid oath hath been maintained as lawfull by many learned Catholike PrieÅ¿ts, and hath been taken by the moÅ¿t part of thoÅ¿e Lay-Catholikes, to whom it hath been tendered; aÅ¿Å¿uring themÅ¿elues that his HolineÅ¿Å¿e command for the refuÅ¿ing thereof, being onely a declaratiue precept, and not grounded vpon any infallible definition, but at the moÅ¿t vpon a probable opinion, that the Pope hath power to depoÅ¿e Princes (which is the maine Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the oath, as my AduerÅ¿arie hereIn the end of his Preface. confeÅ¿Å¿eth, and Fa: Suarez, Lib. 6. defenÅ¿. a cap. 2. alÅ¿o before him expreÅ¿Å¿ely acknowledgeth, is not, according to Suarez doctrine, of force to binde them, eÅ¿pecially with Å¿o great preiudice to his MaieÅ¿tie and themÅ¿elues, to embrace an vncertaine and doubtfull opinion, or to obey the Popes declaratiue precept grounded therevpon.

2 I therefore with other Catholikes conÅ¿idering how greatly this oath doth concerne our allegiance, and obedience due to God and CaeÅ¿ar, and the great harme both Å¿pirituall and temporall, which may enÅ¿ue by breach thereof, thought it our beÅ¿t courÅ¿e, to Å¿et downe Å¿incerely all the chiefeÅ¿t arguments, which haue been hitherto by any Author, or which might in our iudgements be obiected by any againÅ¿t the Å¿aid oath, together with the anÅ¿wers, which haue been, or might be brought to the Å¿ame Obiections, and withall dutifull Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to propound them to his HolineÅ¿Å¿e,

Bellarmine, or Å¿ome other Catholike Doctors, who are no neceÅ¿Å¿arie rule of the Catholike faith, but according to Catholike doctrine neceÅ¿Å¿arily to be beleeued by all men, repugnant to faith and Å¿aluation, as his HolineÅ¿Å¿e affirmeth in his Breues. And this I performed in my Theologicall DiÅ¿putation, partly at the requeÅ¿t of many Catholikes, whoÅ¿e caÅ¿e I greatly pittied, but chiefely for the duty I owed to God, Religion, my Prince and Countrey: Neither did I intend in that DiÅ¿putation to affirme any thing of my Å¿elfe, but as repreÅ¿enting the perÅ¿ons of thoÅ¿e, who were perÅ¿waded, that the oath may, or may not be lawfully taken. And becauÅ¿e when the Å¿aid DiÅ¿putation was in the preÅ¿Å¿e, & almoÅ¿t finiÅ¿hed, there came to my hands an EngliÅ¿h booke compoÅ¿ed by F.T. and entituled a Supplement to the DiÅ¿cuÅ¿sion &c. wherein this Authour endeauoured to proue the Å¿aid oath to bee repugnant to all lawes both humane and diuine, and therefore iuÅ¿tly condemned by his HolineÅ¿Å¿e, in that it doth exempt temporall Princes from Excommunication and depoÅ¿ition by the Pope, I thought good to touch briefely in an Admonition to the Reader, both the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of this Authors diÅ¿courÅ¿e, and of the chiefeÅ¿t arguments which hee brought againÅ¿t the oath, and alÅ¿o the anÅ¿wers, which might bee made to them; to the end his HolineÅ¿Å¿e, might be fully informed of all the reaÅ¿ons, which are alledged as well againÅ¿t as for the taking of the oath. 3 But the Å¿aid Authour F. T. who now hath turned backward the firÅ¿t letters of his name into T. F. and is knowne, acknowledged, yea and boaÅ¿ted of by his fauourers to be Mr. Thomas Fitzherbert now an EngliÅ¿h IeÅ¿uite (for which cauÅ¿e I was the more bold to expreÅ¿Å¿e his name) hath of late Å¿et forth a Reply in EngliÅ¿h in defence of his arguments,In the Praeface nu. 2. which I briefely anÅ¿wered in Latine, to the end, Å¿aith he, that our Countreymen, whom it moÅ¿t importeth to vnderÅ¿tand well the qualitie, and Å¿tate of this controuerÅ¿ie, may diÅ¿couer my weakeneÅ¿Å¿e, and auoide the danger of their Å¿oules, whereto they may be drawne by the falÅ¿e fame, and opinion, that many haue conceiued of my Å¿ufficiency. But howÅ¿oeuer my AduerÅ¿arie, or any other bee conceited of my weakeneÅ¿Å¿e or Å¿ufficiencie (for time will make knowne the weakeneÅ¿Å¿e or Å¿ufficiencie of vs both) I doe not doubt (God willing,) but notwithÅ¿tanding all his vaunting bragges, to diÅ¿couer cleerely the weakeneÅ¿Å¿e and inÅ¿ufficiencie of his Reply, albeit hee hath beene furthered with the former writings of many learned men, eÅ¿pecially Card. Bellarmine, Fa: LeÅ¿sius, & now laÅ¿tly of Suarez (from whom he borroweth the chiefeÅ¿t Replyes he bringeth to my anÅ¿weres, yet concealing their names) to omit the many other helpes I want, which he may haue in the place where hee liueth, both by the conference of learned men, & the commoditie of all Å¿orts of books, wherewith that place is furniÅ¿hed. And although hee vÅ¿eth very Å¿piteful, and Å¿landerous Å¿peeches againÅ¿t me (for the which I pray God to forgiue him) thinking thereby to magnifie himÅ¿elfe, diÅ¿grace me and promote his owne cauÅ¿e, but in the end hee will finde that Å¿uch exorbitant and irreligious courÅ¿es will tend to his owne diÅ¿grace and not mine, and hee greatly preiudiciall both to his cauÅ¿e and conÅ¿cience, yet I wil abÅ¿taine from Å¿uch vncharitable and vniuÅ¿t proceedings, and with all modeÅ¿tie I will defend my owne

Apologiae. to vÅ¿e Card. Bellarmines owne words, to be accounted a defaming. Now to draw neere vnto the matter.

4. Before my AduerÅ¿arie come to examine my AnÅ¿were to his arguments, he thinketh it not amiÅ¿Å¿e to Å¿ay Å¿omewhat concerning me, the matter which I handle, and the manner how I proceede therein. FirÅ¿t then touching me he affirmeth,In his Preface num. 3.
that whereas I call my Å¿elfe by the name of Widdrington, it is well knowne to many, that M. Roger Widdrington, vnder whoÅ¿e Å¿haddow I Å¿hroude my Å¿elfe, is farre different from me in qualitie, habit, and profeÅ¿Å¿ion. And albeit
Num. 3. he is not ignorant what my true name, and qualitie is, yet he forbeareth to declare it for iuÅ¿t reÅ¿pects, and will only Å¿ay of me for the preÅ¿ent, that whereas our AduerÅ¿aries haue heretofore leuied, and PreÅ¿t many Å¿ouldiers of their owne profeÅ¿Å¿ion to maintaine their quarrells againÅ¿t vs, they haue now in this late quarrell of the oath PreÅ¿t one of ours (I meane Å¿aith he, this Authour) who Å¿o much preÅ¿umeth of his owne skill and Å¿trength, that albeit the prouerbe Å¿aith, Ne Hercules contra duos, yet he feareth not to encounter tenne at once, yea hopeth, as it Å¿eemeth, to wreÅ¿t the club out of Hercules his hand, and to beate him with his owne weapon. For he taketh vpon him to ouerthrow Card. Bellarmine with his owne arguments, to batter the fortreÅ¿Å¿e of the Catholike Church with her owne Canons, and conÅ¿titutions &c.

5. But firÅ¿t, whether Roger Widdrington be the true or Å¿uppoÅ¿ed, the Å¿ole, or ioint Authour of that DiÅ¿putation, it little auaileth to the matter, which is now in controuerÅ¿ie: and when my AduerÅ¿arie Å¿hall name more plainely that perÅ¿on, whom he forbearing, as he
Å¿aith, to name, yet cunningly nameth, I doubt not, but that hee will not be afraid to anÅ¿were him more fully; neither will all my AduerÅ¿aries clamours, and threatnings diÅ¿courage him from defending the truth, his Prince, and Countrey, for the loue wherof, & not for any hope of temporall lucre or preferment, or for to Å¿hew his wit as my AduerÅ¿ary falÅ¿ly affirmeth, he will not be aÅ¿hamed to be PreÅ¿t on to write againÅ¿t Mr. Fitzherbert, or any other Å¿uch like Authour, who liuing in other Countries, and out of danger to looÅ¿e any thing, but rather in hope to obtaine preferment by their writings, would preÅ¿Å¿e EngliÅ¿h Catholikes to defend with danger of looÅ¿ing all they haue, and of incurring his MaieÅ¿ties high diÅ¿pleaÅ¿uer that doctrine for the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes to be of faith, which the State of France hath accounted Å¿candalous, Å¿editious, damnable, and pernicious. In the meane time let this Å¿uffice, that he is a childe of the Catholike Romane Church, and as good a Catholike, if not better then Mr. Fitzherbert is, if we will dulie conÅ¿ider the true nature and definition of a Catholike, and that he is no true Catholike, who with true Catholike and Å¿upernaturall faith beleeueth doubtfull, diÅ¿putable, and vncertaine opinions, and which conÅ¿equently are Å¿ubiect to errour, to which true Catholike faith cannot in any wiÅ¿e be expoÅ¿ed.

6. Secondly, it is vntrue, that I doe preÅ¿ume Å¿o much of my owne skill and Å¿trength, that I dare aduenture to wreÅ¿t out the club of Hercules his hand, as my AduerÅ¿arie affirmeth or to encounter vpon equall tearmes with Card. Bellarmine, or any one of thoÅ¿e learned writers, whom I named in my DiÅ¿putation, accounting my Å¿elfe to be farre inferior to euery one of them in skill and Å¿trength (only excepting this my AduerÅ¿arie, whoÅ¿e skill and Å¿trength I doe not greatly feare, it being well knowne of what Å¿ufficiencie he is, and that his skill in PhiloÅ¿ophie, or Schoole Diuinitie

And therefore very falÅ¿e, and friuolous is that, which my AduerÅ¿arie affirmeth Num 4. and 5. that Widdrington (for Å¿o Å¿till I will call my Å¿elfe) taketh vpon him to batter the fortreÅ¿Å¿e of the Catholike Church with her owne Canons, and conÅ¿titutions, and to vndermine the immoueable rocke of S. Peter with his owne inÅ¿truments, and all this he doth with Å¿uch art and Å¿leight, that whiles he fighteth againÅ¿t the Church, he pretendeth to be a friend and childe of the Church, and albeit he impugne the Popes authority, yet he dedicateth his booke to the Pope, laughing vpon him, whiles he woundeth him, and betraying ChriÅ¿t with a kiÅ¿Å¿e, as Iudas did. Neither doe I vndermine that immoueable rocke of S. And although Trithemius by the word, ScholaÅ¿tikes or Schoolemen, had vnderÅ¿tood not onely Students in Diuinity in generall, but particularly thoÅ¿e, that profeÅ¿Å¿e ScholaÅ¿ticall Diuinity, as it is diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed from poÅ¿itiue, yet that he had beene therein manifeÅ¿tly deceiued, as D. PhyÅ¿icians may eaÅ¿ily know, when learned Lawyers are at Å¿trife concerning a point of Law, and Å¿o both of them may eaÅ¿ily know, when learned Diuines are at contention about a Theologicall queÅ¿tion; and writers of hiÅ¿tories may alÅ¿o know, when Diuines or Lawyers are at debate about any point of Diuinity or Law, and may alÅ¿o, without paÅ¿Å¿ing the bounds of their profeÅ¿Å¿ion relate the Å¿ame to others. And therefore it is no maruell, that Trithemius being not onely a meere HiÅ¿toriographer, but alÅ¿o a learned poÅ¿itiue Diuine, as by his manifold workes it doth cleerely appeare, might eaÅ¿ily perceiue, that it was at that time a controuerÅ¿ie among Scholasticall Diuines, whether the Pope had authoritie to depoÅ¿e the Emperour or no. Neither is it neceÅ¿Å¿arie, that the controuerÅ¿ie Å¿hould be made knowen by printed books, but it Å¿ufficeth that it bee made manifeÅ¿t by word of mouth, and publike oppoÅ¿ition and contradiction in Schooles, as all men, who frequent the Schools, may by daily experience moÅ¿t cleerely perceiue.

7. Thirdly, but if Trithemius, Å¿aith D. Schulckenius call Schoolemen, Gramarians, Poets, HiÅ¿toriographers, he Å¿aith Å¿omething. For truely this point is in controuerÅ¿ie among Grammarians as Valla, HiÅ¿toriographers as Sigebert, Poets as Dantes, and in their opinions the Iudge hath not as yet decided the queÅ¿tion. Marke now the fraud and cunning of this man. For who would not by this his anÅ¿wer imagine, but that thoÅ¿e three Authours were meere Grammarians, HiÅ¿toriographers, Poets, and not Diuines? where as it is manifeÅ¿t, that although for Grammar, HiÅ¿tories, and Poetry they were Å¿ingular, and inferiour to none of their times, yet
they were all of them alÅ¿o learned Diuines, as Trithemius in his book de EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticis Scriptoribus doth Å¿ufficiently witneÅ¿Å¿e. Laurentius Valla, Å¿aith hee, In verbo Laurentius Valla. a noble man of Rome, the Prince by farre of Grammarians of this age, a PhiloÅ¿opher, Rhetorician, and a moÅ¿t excellent Diuine &c. Dantes, Å¿aith he,In verbo Dantes.
by Country a Florentine, a most great Å¿tudent in his time of all men, as well in Diuine Scriptures as Secular learning, and very learned, a PhiloÅ¿opher, and a Poet inferiour to none of that age. Sigebert, Å¿aith he,In verbo Sigebertus.
a monke of the order of S. Benedict, a moÅ¿t great Å¿tudent from his youth in Diuine Scriptures, and very learned, and in Å¿ecular learning inferiour i â¢ none of his time. And yet D. Schulckenius would cunningly perÅ¿wade his Reader, that Valla was a meere Grammarian, Dantes a meere Poet, and Sigebert a meere HiÅ¿toriographer. Moreouer, Trithemius could not by Schoolemen only vnderÅ¿tand Valla, Dantes and Sigebert; for that his words are of the preÅ¿ent tence and time; He doth not Å¿ay, It hath beene a controuerÅ¿ie among the Schoole-men, but it is a controuerÅ¿ie among the School-men, & adhuc, and as yet, till now, hitherto, to this preÅ¿ent time, the queÅ¿tion is not decided by the Iudge. Therefore Trithemius his words are not Å¿o to bee vnderÅ¿tood, as D. Schulckenius expoundeth them, that in the opinion of Valla, Dantes and Sigebert, who all liued aboue a hundredFor Sigebert liued in the yere 1111 Dantes in the yeere 1321. Valla in the yeere 1420. and Trithemius in the yeere 1519. yeeres before Trithemius his time, but according to his owne opinion the queÅ¿tion is not at this preÅ¿ent decided by the Iudge.

8 Fourthly, But what neede is there, Å¿aith D. Schulckenius, to aske aduiÅ¿e of Trithemius, who oftentimes hath erred in the hiÅ¿torie, which he profeÅ¿Å¿eth, as Antonie PoÅ¿Å¿euine hath noted in his Apparatus; But firÅ¿t, be it Å¿o, that Trithemius giuing credit to the relation of others, hath erred Å¿ometimes in his hiÅ¿torie (for all thoÅ¿e oftentimes PoÅ¿Å¿euine doth in particular reduce onely to three) muÅ¿t therefore no credit be giuen to other his relations; eÅ¿pecially, when other
Doctours of the Å¿ame age doe relate the Å¿ame? And doth not Card: Bellarmine himÅ¿elfe confeÅ¿Å¿e, as appeareth by his Recognitions, that he hath oftentimes erred in points of Diuinitie, which depend not Å¿o much vpon relation, as vpon iudgement? muÅ¿t therefore no credit be giuen hereafter to his judgement in other points of Diuinitie? or will he like it well, that his own words, which he vÅ¿eth here againÅ¿t Trithemius, be retorted backe vpon himÅ¿elfe, what neede is there to aske the aduiÅ¿e of Card: Bellarmine, who, as he himÅ¿elfe confeÅ¿Å¿eth, hath oftentimes erred in points of Diuinitie, which he profeÅ¿Å¿eth.

9 Secondly, obÅ¿erue good Reader, how palpably and groÅ¿Å¿ely, not to Å¿ay Å¿hamefully, both PoÅ¿Å¿euine, and D. Schulckenius alÅ¿o, giuing credit to PoÅ¿Å¿euine, haue themÅ¿elues erred, in reprehending vnworthily Trithemius his errours. For three particular things PoÅ¿Å¿euine relateth In verbo Ioannes Trithemius., wherein he affirmeth Trithemius to haue erred in his hiÅ¿torie. The first is, in that Trithemius affirmeth In verbo Laurentius IuÅ¿tin. Laurentius IuÅ¿tinianus to haue been of the Order of the CeleÅ¿tines. And neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e PoÅ¿Å¿euine himÅ¿elfe a little after in the word Laurentius IuÅ¿tinianus doth in expreÅ¿Å¿e words affirme, that he was of that Order. Laurentius IuÅ¿tinianus, Å¿aith PoÅ¿Å¿euine, a Æ²enetian, of the Order of the CeleÅ¿tines, the first Patriarch of Venice &c. The Å¿econd is, in that Trithemius affirmeth one Hugo a Dominican and Cardinall to be BarchionenÅ¿is, and doth not make mention whether he was of Barcilona in France or in Spaine. But although Trithemius was not Å¿o exact in diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing thoÅ¿e two places, yet conÅ¿idering that euery errour includeth a falÅ¿hood, and Trithemius in the aforeÅ¿aid relation affirmed no falÅ¿hood or vntruth, hee can not iuÅ¿tly by PoÅ¿Å¿euine be therefore taxed of errour.

10 The third errour, wherewith PoÅ¿Å¿euine chargeth them, is, in that hee affirmeth Abbot Ioachim to haue beene condemned in a generall Councell, where
as the Councell, Å¿aith PoÅ¿Å¿euine, did not condemne the man, but the doctrine, which was againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿ter of the Sentences. But truly I can not but greatly maruell, how PoÅ¿Å¿euine could be Å¿o groÅ¿Å¿ely miÅ¿taken, vnleÅ¿Å¿e he would of Å¿et purpoÅ¿e forge Å¿omething, whereby he might diÅ¿grace Trithemius. For if he had but briefely runne ouer that place of Trithemius, which he citeth, he could not but haue Å¿eene, that Trithemius did only affirme Ioachims doctrine, and not his perÅ¿on to be condemned in the Councell. Tractatus autem quem Å¿cripÅ¿it &c. But the TreatiÅ¿e (Å¿aith Trithemius In verbo Ioachim Abbas. in the place cited by PoÅ¿Å¿euine) which Abbot Ioachim wrote againÅ¿t Peter Lombard BiÅ¿hop of Paris, is condemned in a Generall Councell, as appeareth in the beginning of the Decretalls, Damnamus.

11 Wherefore to returne backe D. Schulckenius his words, what neede had D. Schulckenius to aske aduice of PoÅ¿Å¿euine touching Trithemius his errours, Å¿eeing that PoÅ¿Å¿euine himÅ¿elfe hath therein not onely groÅ¿Å¿ely erred, but alÅ¿o in other his relations, as in affirming Iohn GerÅ¿on Chancelour of Paris to be of the Order of the CeleÅ¿tines (wherein alÅ¿o Card: Bellarmine in his late treatiÅ¿e of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall writers hath erred with him) yea and Å¿ometimes which is leÅ¿Å¿e excuÅ¿able, when of Å¿et purpoÅ¿e he pretendeth to recall and amend his former errour; as in verbo Durandus Ã S. Porciano, whom in his former Edition, as he Å¿aith (for I neuer Å¿aw it) he affirmed to be BiÅ¿hop of Melda, as truly he was, and of the Order of S. Dominike: and now, forÅ¿ooth, in his corrected Edition he will needs haue him to be BiÅ¿hop of Liege, and to haue liued in the yeare 1035. and that Hermannus Contractus, who liued in the yeare 1054. maketh mention of him, and yet he will alÅ¿o haue him to be of the Order of Dominike: And neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e PoÅ¿Å¿euine himÅ¿elfe a little before In verbo Dominicus Guzmannus. affirmed, that S. Dominike dyed in the yeare 1221. which was two hundred fourteene yeares after
Durandus flouriÅ¿hed. Now let D. Schulckenius, or any other, who maketh Å¿o great account of PoÅ¿Å¿euines Apparatus, either accord theÅ¿e two, that Durandus Ã S. Porciano was according to PoÅ¿Å¿euine of the Order of S. Dominike, and yet that according to the Å¿ame PoÅ¿Å¿euine he liued well neere 200. yeares before S. Dominike did inÅ¿titute his Order, or elÅ¿e not to giue hereafter Å¿o great credit to all that PoÅ¿Å¿euine affirmeth, Å¿eeing that he hath Å¿o groÅ¿Å¿ely erred both in falÅ¿ly taxing Trithemius of thoÅ¿e errours, and alÅ¿o (which is more groÅ¿Å¿e) when purpoÅ¿ely he endeauoured to amend his owne errour.

12 LaÅ¿tly, we haue, Å¿aith D Schulckenius, the common opinion of Doctours, and decrees of Councells, which doe make the matter cleare. And therefore although among learned Diuines and Lawyers there be a controuerÅ¿ie concerning the manner how the Pope may doe it, yet there is no queÅ¿tion whether he hath power to doe it. But first we haue the authoritie of Trithemius, that it is a controuerÅ¿ie among the Schoolemen, and as yet not decided by the Iudge, not onely in what manner the Pope may depoÅ¿e the Emperour, but whether he hath any power at all to depoÅ¿e him. Then we haue the authoritie of Almaine a learned Schoole-Diuine, and a ClaÅ¿Å¿icall Doctour, that it is the opinion of very many Doctours, that the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall power by the inÅ¿titution of ChriÅ¿t can onely inflict Å¿pirituall CenÅ¿ures, and not any temporall puniÅ¿hment, as death, exile, priuation of goods, much leÅ¿Å¿e of kingdomes, nay nor Å¿o much as impriÅ¿onment. And therefore although it be the more common opinion of Doctours, that the Pope hath power to depoÅ¿e Princes, eÅ¿pecially of Lawyers, who as Pope Pius the fift did plainely confeÅ¿Å¿e to that famous Lawyer Nauarre
in Comment. Å¿uper cap: Non liceat Papae. 12. q. 2. Â§ 3. num: 6., doe attribute more authoritie to the Pope then is Å¿ufficient (for that the greateÅ¿t part of thoÅ¿e Authours cited by Card: Bellarmine, who in expreÅ¿Å¿e words affirme, that the Pope hath Å¿uch a power, are Lawyers,
men alÅ¿o for the moÅ¿t part vnskilfull in Diuine Scriptures, and the law of God, as Dominicus Sotus affirmeth Jn 4o. diÅ¿t. 18. q. 1. ar. 1.) yet it is not the more common opinion of Doctours, that it is a cleare and certaine doctrine not to be called in queÅ¿tion by any Catholike, that the Pope hath Å¿uch a power.

13. Few only Diuines there are, & for the moÅ¿t part IeÅ¿uites who of late yeares haue by might and maine endeauoured without Å¿ufficient grounds to make the matter cleare, and to be an vndoubted point of faith. But vntill they bring more cleare decrees of Councells, or more pregnant proofes from holy Scriptures, then hitherto they haue brought, they will neuer make the matter cleare, but Å¿till it will remaine a controuerÅ¿ie among Catholikes, not only in what maner the Pope may, but whether he hath any power at all to depoÅ¿e the Emperour or no, as it was in Trithemius and Almaines time, Å¿ince which time no cleare decree of any Councell hath been made to that purpoÅ¿e, for all the decrees of Councells, which by Card. Bellarmine are vrged to proue that doctrine, and haue been anÅ¿wered by me and others, and Å¿hall beneath be anÅ¿wered more at large, were long before their time. And thus much concerning the firÅ¿t authoritie of Trithemius, and Almaine.

div.head: Chap. 2.

argument.p: Wherein the authoritie of Albericus Roxiatus a famous Lawyer is briefly debated.

div.p:
1. THe Å¿econd teÅ¿timonie, which I brought in my Theologicall DiÅ¿putation, and alÅ¿o in my Apologie to proue this doctrine for the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes not to be certaine,Jn verbo Albericus Roxiatus. without controuerÅ¿ie, or a point of faith, was of Albericus Roxiatus, a moÅ¿t famous ProfeÅ¿Å¿our, as Trithemius writeth, of the Canon
and Ciuill Law, and a man excellently learned, and according to Fa. Azor Lib. 2. IuÅ¿t. cap. 14. , a ClaÅ¿Å¿ical Doctour, who liued in the yeare 1340. aboue a hundred yeares Å¿ince the Councell of Lateran, which is now Å¿o greatly vrged. For this Authour calleth in queÅ¿tion foure of the moÅ¿t principall Canons or Decrees of Popes regiÅ¿tred in the Canon Law, which do Å¿eeme moÅ¿t to fauour their authoritie to depoÅ¿e Princes, and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of the temporalls, eÅ¿pecially of the Romane Emperour (among which one is that famous, and Å¿o often inculcated by my AduerÅ¿aries, Å¿entence of depoÅ¿ition denounced againÅ¿t Fredericke the Emperour by Pope Innocent the fourth in the preÅ¿ence of the Councell of Lyons) and he affirmeth that none of them are in his opinion agreeable to law, or right, but that they were made by Popes, againÅ¿t the rights, and libertie of the Empire.

2. The PaÅ¿tours of the Church, Å¿aith he,In Dictionario verbo Electio. putting their Å¿ickle into others harueÅ¿t, haue made foure Decrees, or Decretalls. The one concerning the election of the Emperour, which beginneth, Venerabilem, and of this it is there noted by all men. An other is about the depoÅ¿ing of Friderike the Emperour, extra de Å¿ententia & re iudicata cap. Ad ApoÅ¿tolicae in Å¿exto, where alÅ¿o of this it is noted by all men. An other is concerning the diÅ¿cord betwixt Henry the Emperour, and Robert King of Sicily, and the Å¿entence of treaÅ¿on publiÅ¿hed by the Emperour againÅ¿t him: which Decree is in Clementina de Å¿ententia & re iudicata cap. PaÅ¿toralis. Another is in Clementina prima de Iureiurando, that the Emperour is bound to Å¿weare allegiance to the Pope, and concerning Å¿ome authoritie of the Pope ouer the Emperour. Which Decretalls, whether they be iuÅ¿t or no, God he knoweth. For I without preiudice to Å¿ounder aduice do beleeue (and if it Å¿hould be erroneous I recall it) that none of them be agreeable to right. Yea I beleeue that they are publiÅ¿hed againÅ¿t the rights and libertie of the Empire, and I doe thinke that by God they were inÅ¿tituted diÅ¿tinct powers, whereof I haue noted Å¿ufficiently
lege prima Cod. de Summa Trinitate & Fide Catholica. Thus Albericus.

3 ObÅ¿erue now, good Reader, how Å¿leightly D. Sculckenius would Å¿hift of this authoritie, which is Å¿o plaine and manifeÅ¿t. Albericus, Å¿aith he, Å¿peaketh wauering and altogether doubtfull, and he addeth, and if it Å¿hould be erroneous I recall it: and he is conuinced of errour by Azor lib. 10. cap. 6. q. 3. TheÅ¿e be all the exceptions that D. Schulckenius taketh againÅ¿t this authority. But firÅ¿t this word doubtfull or wauering, as out of VaÅ¿quez I obÅ¿erued in my Theologicall DiÅ¿putation
Cap. 10. Å¿ec. 2. nu: 18. 19. 20. & 81., may be taken two manner of waies, either when one is Å¿o doubtfull, that he hath no determinate aÅ¿Å¿ent of either part, but remaineth perplex betwixt both, iudging neither part to be either true or falÅ¿e, in which Å¿enÅ¿e that word, altogether doubtfull, which D. Schulkenius vÅ¿eth here, if he will not Å¿peake improperly, can only be taken; and when we are thus doubtfull concerning any matter, we are alwaies bound to chuÅ¿e the Å¿urer part; neither is it lawfull to do any thing with a doubtfull conÅ¿cience, taking doubtfull in this Å¿enÅ¿e: Or elÅ¿e the word, doubtfull, may be taken, when wee haue a determinate aÅ¿Å¿ent or iudgement that one part is true or falÅ¿e, but yet we are not certaine, and therefore haue Å¿ome feare of the contrarie, which feare doth not exclude a determinate aÅ¿Å¿ent and iudgement that one part is true, for euery aÅ¿Å¿ent, iudgement or opinion, which is only probable, doth alwaies imply a feare; but feare conÅ¿iÅ¿teth in this, that he who is fearefull, or iudgeth with feare, hath two aÅ¿Å¿ents or iudgements, the one direct, whereby he iudgeth determinately, that one part is true, the other reflexe, whereby he iudgeth, that although he thinketh it true, yet in very deede it may be falÅ¿e, for that it is not certaine, but DiÅ¿putable and in controuerÅ¿ie among Doctours, and therefore only probable: and when we are thus doubtfull or fearefull concerning any matter, we are not bound to chuÅ¿e
the Å¿urer part, but it is Å¿ufficient to chuÅ¿e that which is probable, neither is it vnlawfull to doe any thing with Å¿uch a doubtfull, or fearefull conÅ¿cience, as in that place I declared out of VaÅ¿quez.

4. Now if D. Schulckenius by thoÅ¿e wordes, wauering and altogether doubtfull, vnderÅ¿tand, as of neceÅ¿Å¿itie he muÅ¿t, if he will Å¿peake properly, that Albericus had no determinate aÅ¿Å¿ent, iudgement, or opinion concerning the vniuÅ¿tice of thoÅ¿e Decretalls, this is manifeÅ¿tly falÅ¿e, and thoÅ¿e words, I doe beleeue that they are not agreeable to right, and I doe beleeue that they are publiÅ¿hed againÅ¿t the rights and libertie of the Empire &c. doe clearely conuince D. Schulkenius of apparant vntruth. But if D. Schulckenius by thoÅ¿e words wauering and altogether doubtfull, doe onely meane, that Albericus was indeed of opinion, that thoÅ¿e Decretalls were vniuÅ¿t, yet he did not hold his opinion for certaine, and without all controuerÅ¿ie, and therefore was not obÅ¿tinate in his owne opinion, but was readie to recall it, if it Å¿hould proue to be erroneous, and that hee would not condemne other men, that Å¿hould thinke the contrarie, (as now adaies it is too frequent to condemne other men) this is very true; for Å¿o much only doe import thoÅ¿e his wordes, and I do beleeue vnder correction, or without preiudice to Å¿ounder aduiÅ¿e, and if it Å¿hould be erroneous I recall it; this neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e doth not hinder, but that we haue the opinion of a man excellently learned, and of a ClaÅ¿Å¿icall Doctour, that the Å¿entence of depoÅ¿ition denounced againÅ¿t Frederike the Emperour by Pope Innocent the fourth in the preÅ¿ence of the Councell of Lyons, and three other famous Decrees of Popes regiÅ¿tred in the Canon Law touching the Popes power to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of temporalls, were vniuÅ¿t, and made againÅ¿t the rights and libertie of the Empire.

5. Secondly, but Albericus is conuinced, Å¿aith D. Schulckenius, of error by Azor. But beÅ¿ides that this
letteth not, but that Albericus is of opinion, that the Pope hath no power to depoÅ¿e Princes, this alÅ¿o is euen as true, as that which D. Schulckenius Å¿aid before concerning the errours, which he Å¿aid PoÅ¿Å¿euine had obÅ¿erued in Trithemius his hiÅ¿torie. For beÅ¿ides that all the arguments, which Azor bringeth to proue in generall, the Popes authoritie ouer the Emperour in temporalls, are but triuiall, and haue been alreadie anÅ¿wered partly by D. Barclay, partly by my Å¿elfe, and now of late very exactly by Mr. Iohn Barclay, to whom as yet no anÅ¿were hath beene made, one only argument in particular Azor vrgeth againÅ¿t Albericus, which is this, that the Romane Emperour was inÅ¿tituted by the authoritie of the Church, by whoÅ¿e grant alÅ¿o the Romane Empire was tranÅ¿lated from the Grecians to the Germanes or Frenchmen, and that he is created as a Patron, defendour, Protector, and Tutour of the Church, from whence he inferreth, that the Pope did not put his Å¿ickle into another mans harueÅ¿t, but did vÅ¿e his owne right, when hee made that Canon concerning the election of the Emperour, and when he exacteth an oath of the Emperour.

6. But that this is no conuincing proofe, I Å¿hewed clearely in my Apologie Num 404. & Å¿eq.. For the Romane Empire was not inÅ¿tituted by the authoritie of the Romane Church, Å¿eeing that he was inÅ¿tituted before there was any Romane Church at all, and continued for a long time together the Soueraigne Lord in temporalls of the Romane Church. Neither was the Romane Empire tranÅ¿lated from the Grecians to the Germans or French men by the grant of the Romane Church, if by the Romane Church be meant onely the Cleargie of Rome, but it was tranÅ¿lated by the grant, Å¿uffrages, and authoritie alÅ¿o of the Laitie, who in the weÅ¿t parts were Å¿ubiect to the Romane Empire. True alÅ¿o it is, that all Catholike Princes ought to be Patrons, defenders, and protectours of the Romane Church (but the Romane Emperour more Å¿pecially) they being children
and members of the Catholike Romane Church, and euery member is bound to defend eath other, but eÅ¿pecially to defend the head. And therefore I will eaÅ¿ily grant, that the Pope may exact, if need require, not only of the Romane Emperour, but alÅ¿o of all other Catholike Princes an oath of Å¿pirituall allegiance, but that Catholike Princes are Å¿ubiect to the Pope in temporalls, and that the Pope may exact of them an oath of temporall allegiance, this is that I vtterly deny, neither will Card. Bellarmine, or any other be able by any Å¿ufficient argument to conuince the contrary; wherefore it cannot with any Å¿hew of probabilitie be denied, but that we haue the teÅ¿timonie of Albericus, a man excellently learned, and a ClaÅ¿Å¿icall Doctour, that the Pope hath no authoritie to depoÅ¿e Soueraigne Princes, and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of their temporall dominions.

div.head: Chap. 3.

argument.p: Wherein the authoritie of Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, a famous Doctour of Paris, is examined, and the exceptions of D. Schulckenius againÅ¿t it are proued to be inÅ¿ufficient.

div.p:
1. THe third authoritie, which I brought in my Theologicall DiÅ¿putation
Cap. 3. Å¿ec. 3. num. 7. and alÅ¿o in my Apologie
Num. 121., was of Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is. a famous Diuine of the Order of S. Dominike, and as Trithemius relatethIn verbo Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is., moÅ¿t learned in the holy Scriptures, and who in the VniuerÅ¿itie of Paris was for a long time together a publike ProfeÅ¿Å¿our, and left behind him many DiÅ¿ciples. He flouriÅ¿hed about the yeare 1280. which was 65. yeares after the great Councell of Lateran, which is now adaies Å¿o greatly vrged by our AduerÅ¿aries. This Doctour therefore although he be of opinion, that if a King Å¿hould become an heretike, and incorrigible, and a contemner of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall CenÅ¿ures, the Pope may do Å¿omewhat with the people,
whereby the King may be depriued of his Secular dignitie, and be depoÅ¿ed by the people, to wit, he may excommunicate all thoÅ¿e, to whom it belongeth to depoÅ¿e the king, who Å¿hould obey him as their Soueraigne: NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e he is cleerely of this opinion, that it belongeth not to the Pope, to depoÅ¿e iuridically Kings or Emperours for any crime whatÅ¿oeuer although it be Å¿pirituall, or which is all one to depriue them Almainus de poteÅ¿t. Eccl. q. 2. cap. 8. of their kingdomes by a definitiue Å¿entence, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that after the Å¿entence be publiÅ¿hed they Å¿hall haue no more regall power and authoritie. For he affirmeth, De poteÅ¿t. Regia & Papali cap. 14. ad. 20. that excommunication, or Å¿uch like Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hment is the laÅ¿t, which may be inflicted by a Å¿pirituall Iudge. For although, Å¿aith he, it belong to an EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Iudge to recall men to God, and to withdraw them from Å¿inne, yet he hath not power to doe this, but by vÅ¿ing thoÅ¿e meanes, which be giuen him by God, which is by excluding them from the Sacraments, and participation of the faithfull. Wherefore although PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is be of opinion, that the temporall common-wealth hath in Å¿ome cauÅ¿es of great moment authoritie to depoÅ¿e their Prince (with which queÅ¿tion I doe not intend at this time to intermeddle) yet concerning the principall controuerÅ¿ie, which is betwixt me and Card. Bellarmine, to wit, whether it be hereticall erroneous, or temerarious to affirme, that the Pope hath no power to depriue Princes of their Royall right and authoritie, Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is doth moÅ¿t plainely, as I haue now Å¿hewed, contradict the opinion of Card. Bellarmine. Thus I wrote in my Theologicall DiÅ¿putation.

2 Marke now, good Reader, with what fraude and falÅ¿hood D. Schulckenius endeauoureth to paÅ¿Å¿e ouer this authoritie. Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, Å¿aith he Pag. 64. 65. 66. ad num: 4., is not for the contrarie opinion. For although he giueth leÅ¿Å¿e to the Pope, then he ought, yet he giueth as much as Å¿ufficeth for our purpoÅ¿e. For what doth it appertaine to the queÅ¿tion which is in hand, whether the Pope doe depoÅ¿e immediately
by his Å¿entence, or that he may by his right withdraw his Å¿ubiects from their obedience and cauÅ¿e them to depoÅ¿e? But who would not admire the wonderfull boldnes of this man? For the onely queÅ¿tion betwixt me and Card. Bellarmine is, and euer hath been, whether the Pope hath authoritie to depriue Princes of their Kingdomes immediately by his Å¿entence, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that after his Å¿entence of depriuation be denounced, they, who before were Kings and had true Regall authoritie, are then no more Kings, and haue no true and lawfull right to reigne; and yet now he being preÅ¿Å¿ed with the authoritie of Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, bluÅ¿heth not to affirme, that it doth not appertaine to the preÅ¿ent queÅ¿tion, whether the Pope may depoÅ¿e immediately by his Å¿entence, which neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e is the onely queÅ¿tion betwixt him and me, or by commanding and cauÅ¿ing the temporall Common-wealth to depoÅ¿e their Prince, with which queÅ¿tion I haue Å¿undry times in my Apologie affirmed that I would not intermeddle. For moÅ¿t certaine it is, euen according to Card: Bellarmines owne doctrinein Tract: contra Barcl. cap. 21. pag. 202. , that the Pope can not withdraw, diÅ¿charge, or abÅ¿olue Å¿ubiects from their obedience immediatly by his Å¿entence, vnles he haue authoritie to depriue immediately & by his Å¿entence their Prince of his Princely power and authoritie, for that authoritie in a Prince, and obedience in Å¿ubiects are correlatiues, and one dependeth on the other, and the obligation of obedience doth Å¿o long endure in the Subiect, as the dignitie, power, or IuriÅ¿diction doth endure in the Superiour, Å¿aith Suarezin DefenÅ¿ione fides &c. lib. 6. cap: 3. nu. 6. , and to deny obedience to a Prince Å¿o long as he remaineth Prince, and is not depriued of his Princely power, is clearely repugnant, Å¿aith Card: Bellarminein Tract: contra Barcl: cap. 21. p. 202. , to the law of God, and nature.

3 This therfore is the opinion of PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is touching the Popes authoritie to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of the temporall goods, or dominions either of Kings, or priuate men. And firÅ¿t concerning the goods of priuate men hee
affirmethDe poteÅ¿t. Regia & Pap. cap: 6. 7. , that the Pope is not a Lord, to whom the propertie of Church liuings doth belong, but onely a diÅ¿pencer of them, but of the goods of Laymen he is not Å¿o much as a diÅ¿pencer; vnleÅ¿Å¿e perchance in extreame neceÅ¿Å¿itie of the Church, in which neceÅ¿Å¿itie alÅ¿o he is not a diÅ¿pencer, but a declarer of the law. And becauÅ¿e in extreame neceÅ¿Å¿itie of faith and manners, all the goods of the faithfull, yea and Chalices of Churches are to be communicated, the Pope, who is Å¿upreme not onely of the Cleargie, but of all the faithfull, as they are faithfull, hath authoritie, as he is generall informer of faith and manners, in caÅ¿e of extreame neceÅ¿Å¿itie of faith and manners to diÅ¿pence in this caÅ¿e the goods of the faithfull, & to ordaine them to be expoÅ¿ed, as it is expedient for the coÌmon neceÅ¿Å¿itie of faith, which other wiÅ¿e would be ouerthrown by the invaÅ¿ion of PagaÌs, or other Å¿uch like accident. And this ordination of the Pope is only a declaration of the law, to which he may by EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall CenÅ¿ures compell the faithfull. But in caÅ¿es not of neceÅ¿Å¿itie, but of Å¿ome Å¿peciall vtilitie, or when it is not apparant, that the goods of Lay-men doe helpe Å¿uch vtilitie, or neceÅ¿Å¿itie, the Pope hath not authoritie to compell any man, but concerning this hee may giue indulgences for giuing aide to the faithfull, and no other thing is granted him in my opinion. Thus writeth PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is. wherefore in his opinion the Pope hath no authoritie to depriue a Lay-man of his goods, or any part thereof, euen in neceÅ¿Å¿itie of faith and manners, but onely to declare, that he is bound by the law of God to giue Å¿uch part of his goods, as the neceÅ¿Å¿itie of the Church Å¿hall require; which if he neglect to doe, the Pope hath no other authoritie to compell him therevnto, then by EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall CenÅ¿ures, which are the laÅ¿t puniÅ¿hments, which the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall power by the inÅ¿titution of ChriÅ¿t can inflict.

4 In the very like manner PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is diÅ¿courÅ¿eth of the diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of Kingdomes, and of depoÅ¿ing temporall Princes, as I before related out of him.
For firÅ¿t he affirmeth, that the Pope hath no authoritie to depoÅ¿e a King iuridically, or, which is all one, to depriue him by a iuridicall Å¿entence of his right to reigne; and Å¿econdly, that the people, or temporall common-wealth may, and in Å¿ome exorbitant caÅ¿es are bound to depoÅ¿e their Prince; and Å¿o the Pope not by a iuridicall Å¿entence of depriuation, but by declaring what the people are by the law of God bound to doe, and by EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall CenÅ¿ures compelling them therevnto, may according to PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, concurre to the depoÅ¿ing of a Prince by meanes of the people, which if the people, notwithÅ¿tanding the Popes CenÅ¿ures neglect to doe, the Pope hath no further power to depoÅ¿e him, for that EccleÅ¿iasticall CenÅ¿ures are, according to him, the last puniÅ¿hment, which the EccleÅ¿iasticall power can inflict.

5 Wherefore two things are affirmed by PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, the one, that the Pope hath no authoritie to depriue Princes immediately by his Å¿entence of their Princely power, and this is that only, which is in controuerÅ¿ie betwixt mee and Card: Bellarmine: the other, that the people, or temporall common-wealth haue that authoritie in Å¿ome exorbitant caÅ¿es: and this is only a philoÅ¿ophicall queÅ¿tion, and wherewith I would neuer intermeddle, as being impertinent to the queÅ¿tion concerning the Popes authoritie to depriue him. And although many Catholike Doctors doe agree with PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is in this point, yet many other learned Catholikes, whom I cited in my Apologie
Num. 411., doe diÅ¿Å¿ent from him herein, to which opinion doe incline very many of the ancient Fathers, who expounding thoÅ¿e words of the King and Prophet, PÅ¿al: 50. I haue Å¿inned to thee alone, doe affirme, that Soueraigne Princes, for that they are inferiour to God alone, to wit, in temporalls, can be puniÅ¿hed with temporall puniÅ¿hments by God alone. And therefore D. Schulckenius may be greatly aÅ¿hamed to affirme Å¿o boldly, that
PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is doth not make for my opinion, and that it doth not appertaine to the queÅ¿tion which is in hand, whether the Pope may depoÅ¿e Princes immediately by his Å¿entence, or by meanes of the people, Å¿eeing that the onely queÅ¿tion betwixt vs is, whether the Pope hath power to depriue Princes of their Royall power immediately by his Å¿entence, and not what authoritie the common-wealth hath to depriue them.

6 But D. Schulckenius perceiuing, that this his anÅ¿wer to the authoritie of PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is was but a meere Å¿hift and euaÅ¿ion, hath reÅ¿erued but not in this place another anÅ¿wer, whereby he imagined to cleane ouerthrow the authority of this famous Doctour and Schoole-Diuine. Bellarmine to prooue the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, Quid tu denuo vÅ¿urpare gladium tentas &c. wherof beneath Part. 2. ca. 9. I will treate more at large, in confirmation of which my anÅ¿wer I cited the authoritie of Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, D. Schulckenius writeth thus: There is no great regard to bee had of the authoritie of Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is whatÅ¿oeuer he Å¿aith, for that other his errours are condemned by the Church in the common Extrauagant Vas electionis: and alÅ¿o in the 14. chapter of the Å¿ame TreatiÅ¿e hee mingleth many errours. Another cenÅ¿ure but more temperate Card. Bellarmine giueth of him in his booke of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall writers. Ioannnes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, Å¿aith he, Pag. 380. of the Order of the Preachers, was famous about the yeere 1296. Hee wrote vpon the foure bookes of the Å¿entences, and diuerÅ¿e Quodlibets: but eÅ¿pecially of Kingly and Papall power, and becauÅ¿e it was his happe to liue in trouble Å¿ometimes by reaÅ¿on of the
diÅ¿cord betweene Pope Boniface the eight, and Philip the faire, King of France, and hee liued and taught at Paris, hee Å¿eemeth to be more inclined towards the King, then the Pope.

5 But truely it is Å¿trange, that men of Å¿uch Å¿ingular learning, and religious profeÅ¿Å¿ion Å¿hould Å¿o raÅ¿hly and without Å¿ufficient grounds be Å¿o tranÅ¿ported, as, contrarie to the rules of ChriÅ¿tian Charitie and IuÅ¿tice, to defame and Å¿launder learned and vertuous men, and thoÅ¿e eÅ¿pecially, who beeing dead cannot defend themÅ¿elues. For firÅ¿t it is an apparant and too too manifeÅ¿t Å¿lander, which Fa: LeÅ¿Å¿ius, Å¿peaking with all dutifull reÅ¿pect to his reuerence, doth affirme that Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is was a SchiÅ¿matike; neither can he out of any approoued Authour, or by any probable reaÅ¿on prooue any Å¿uch thing: and therfore what great account hee hath to make at the dreadfull day of iudgement, for vniuÅ¿tly taking away, as much as lieth in him, the good name of Å¿o famous a man, and in Å¿o fowle and hainous a crime as SchiÅ¿me is, I remit to the examination of his owne conÅ¿cience. BeÅ¿ides, that PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is mingleth many errours in the 14. chapter of his Kingly and Papall power, as D. Schulckenius affirmeth, and that he alledgeth many falÅ¿e citations and hiÅ¿tories, as Fa: LeÅ¿Å¿ius Å¿aith, is alÅ¿o vntrue, and it had beene fitting for them to haue alledged Å¿ome one of them, that thereby Å¿ome credit might haue beene giuen them for the reÅ¿t. VnleÅ¿Å¿e whatÅ¿oeuer is not agreeable to D. Schulckenius his doctrine, which he thinketh to be certaine muÅ¿t bee accounted an errour, and whatÅ¿oeuer Fa. LeÅ¿Å¿ius hath not Å¿eeene. or read muÅ¿t be eÅ¿teemed a falÅ¿e citation or hiÅ¿torie. LeÅ¿Å¿ius doth indiÅ¿creetly carp, Pag. 30. affirming, that he findeth no Å¿uch thing in HoÅ¿tienÅ¿is, yea & that HoÅ¿tienÅ¿is hath not written vpon the chapter Ad Abolendam tit. de Haereticis, as Widdrington iudgeth, as neither vpon other texis. But neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e I found in OÅ¿tienÅ¿is vpon the chapter Ad abolendam that which Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is cited out of him; and to Å¿ay that HoÅ¿tienÅ¿is did not write vpon that chapter Ad abolendam, is Å¿o manifeÅ¿t an vntruth as I obÅ¿erued in another placeIn my Latin Appendix againÅ¿t Fa: Suarez part. 1. Å¿ec. 7 num. 14., that I wonder how F. LeÅ¿Å¿ius, who is reputed to be a man of Å¿o great reading, could be ignorant thereof.

6 Moreouer, that PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is Å¿eemeth to bee more enclined to the King then to the Pope, he then liuing and teaching at Paris, is indeede affirmed, but not prooued by Card. Bellarmine. And if this manner of cenÅ¿uring learned men and excepting againÅ¿t their authority, as men partiall, may be approoued, it is the readie way to ouerthrow the teÅ¿timony almoÅ¿t of all the Authours on both Å¿ides. Regia & Papali c. 21. ad 41.
that Å¿o woorthie men, among whom Å¿ome alÅ¿o were Popes, did write againÅ¿t their conÅ¿cience in fauour of Princes, or for feare of them, is to Å¿tretch foorth his mouth againÅ¿t heauen. 7 Furthermore, neither can D. Schulckenius in my opinion Å¿ufficientlie prooue, that Ioannes de Poliaco, whoÅ¿e errours were condemned by Pope Iohn the 22. in that Extrauagant Vas electionis, was this Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, who made the TreatiÅ¿e of Kingly and Papall power, but Å¿ome other Doctour of Paris, who was called by that name, and liued about that time. Thirdly, there is no Authour that I haue read, who Å¿aith, that Ioannes de Poliaco, whoÅ¿e errours were condemned, was of the Order of the preaching Fryars, neither doth Prateolus, who vÅ¿ually Å¿etteth down, of what Order thoÅ¿e Authours whom he relateth, are, affirme, that this Ioannes de Poliaco was of that Order, whereas moÅ¿t Authors, who Å¿peake of Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, that wrote the TreatiÅ¿e of Kingly and Papall power, doe affirme, that hee was a Dominican Fryar. Fourthly, neither is, there any Authour that I haue read, who doth affirme, that Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is,

Bellarmine in the yeare 1296. both which may very well be true, for that it may very well fall out, that the Å¿ame man may be a famous Teacher and Preacher for Å¿ixteene yeares together, but it is very vnlike, that one man Å¿hould for one and fortie yeares together at the leaÅ¿t be a famous Reader and Preacher, which wee muÅ¿t grant to be true, if Ioannes de Poliaco, whoÅ¿e errours were condemned, and he in perÅ¿on recalled them before the Pope and Cardinalls in publike ConÅ¿iÅ¿torie at Auinion in the yeare 1321. and was commanded to teach and preach in the Schooles, and pulpit the contrarie doctrine, was our Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, who wrote the TreatiÅ¿e of Kingly and papall power, and was famous in the yeare 1280.

But to conclude this point, be it Å¿o, that our Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, and Ioannes de Poliaco were one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame man, which yet, as I haue Å¿hewed, hath no great likelihood, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e the maintaining of thoÅ¿e errors doth little repaire the authoritie of IoaÌnes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is in this point, but rather from hence a forcible argument may bee drawne to proue, that it is no erroneous doctrine, to hould, that the Pope hath no authoritie to depoÅ¿e Princes by his Å¿entence. P â¢ rtiano

In 4. diÅ¿t. 17. q. 6., a famous Doctour of the Å¿ame VniuerÅ¿itie, did maintaine the Å¿ame; and alÅ¿o that he was readie at the firÅ¿t condemnation
thereof to recall it, and to preach the contrary; if at that time the Pope and Cardinalls had alÅ¿o beene perÅ¿waded, that it was an erroneous doctrine to affirme, that the Pope hath no power to depoÅ¿e Princes by his Å¿entence, and that it belongeth to the Pope to recall men to God, and to withdraw them from Å¿inne by no other coerciue meanes, then by excluding them from the Sacraments and participation of the faithfull, and that Excommunication, or Å¿uch like Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hment is the laÅ¿t, which may bee inflicted by the Å¿pirituall Iudge, all which Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is in his treatiÅ¿e of Kingly and papall power did publikely maintaine, without doubt the Pope, if hee had thought this doctrine to be erroneous, would alÅ¿o haue compelled him to recall it, it being Å¿o greatly preiudiciall to his owne Pontificall authoritie. And therefore notwithÅ¿tanding all the exceptions, which Card. Bellarmine and Fa. LeÅ¿Å¿ius do take againÅ¿t Ioannes PariÅ¿ienÅ¿is, we haue the teÅ¿timonie of this learned Catholike, and famous Schole-Diuine, that the Pope hath no authority to depoÅ¿e Princes by his Å¿entence, which is the only queÅ¿tion at this time betweene me, and Card. div.p:

Å¿ec. 3. num. 28., and alÅ¿o in my Apologieb, was of Mr. Doctour Barclay a moÅ¿t learned man, and yet no more learned then religious, (howÅ¿oeuer Å¿ome falÅ¿ly and vnchriÅ¿tianly do Å¿launder him) in his booke de Regno printed at Paris in the yeare 1600. with priueledge of the moÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian King of France, where he affirmeth, that Kings, who doe omit, or are negligent, to keepe Gods commandements, to worÅ¿hip him religiouÅ¿ly,

2. But Card. Bellarmine in his booke againÅ¿t D. Barclay Per totum. little regardeth his authority; and now in his Sculckenius he affirmeth,Pag. 110. ad num. 28.
that Catholikes will make no more account of Barclay, then they do of MarÅ¿ilius de Padua, and of my Å¿elfe (an eaÅ¿ie anÅ¿wer to Å¿hift off the authoritie of any learned Catholike) And againe, who doth not maruaile, Å¿aith D. Schulckenius, that Å¿eeing Card. Bellarmine hath in this point clearely and Å¿oundly after his accuÅ¿tomed manner confuted Barclay, Widdrington durÅ¿t not only aduenture to write againÅ¿t him without Å¿ufficient ground, but alÅ¿o to oppoÅ¿e the Å¿aid Barclay, as a teÅ¿timonie of truth againÅ¿t Card. Bellarmine.

3. But notwithÅ¿tanding this glorious brag of D. Schulckenius Å¿o highly commending himÅ¿elfe, and his cleare and Å¿ound confuting of Barclay after his accuÅ¿tomed manner, it cannot be denied, but that Doctour Barclay was a very learned man, and liued and died like a vertuous Catholike, and ãâã hee was in times paÅ¿t, as PoÅ¿Å¿euine alÅ¿o relateth,In verbo Gulielmus Barclaius. a CounÅ¿eller to the Duke of Lorraine, and MaÅ¿ter of RequeÅ¿ts, and in the vniuerÅ¿ity of MuÅ¿Å¿epont a ProfeÅ¿Å¿our of the Canon and Ciuill Law, and alÅ¿o Deane, and that his booke was printed at Paris with a Å¿peciall priueledge of the moÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian King of France, and is by PoÅ¿Å¿euine related among other approued bookes, and no exception taken by him againÅ¿t it. And therefore who doth not maruell, that

Barclay, a famous and learned Catholike, then of MarÅ¿ilius of Padua, a known and condemned heretike, although not for this point touching the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, but for other his aÅ¿Å¿ertions which I related in my Appendix againÅ¿t Fa. Suarez Wherefore although perchance Å¿ome Catholikes doe with Card. Bellarmine make Å¿mall account of Doctour Barclaies authoritie, as alÅ¿o they would make of the authoritie of any other Catholike, were he neuer Å¿o vertuous or learned, that Å¿hould write againÅ¿t them in this point, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e other Catholikes doe greatly regard his authoritie for the aforeÅ¿aid cauÅ¿e, and they are alÅ¿o perÅ¿waded, that they haue as probable reaÅ¿ons to thinke, that he did not write partially in fauour of Princes or any other perÅ¿on, as that Card. Bellarmine did not write partially in fauour of the Pope, and Å¿ome other of his followers in fauour of him, and their Order.

4 Neither hath D. Schulckenius in very truth any great cauÅ¿e Å¿o greatly to vaunt of his cleare and Å¿ound confuting of D. Barclay, for that both his Å¿onne Mr. Iohn Barclay a learned Catholike hath moÅ¿t clearely Å¿hewed the Å¿aid confutation to be very vnÅ¿ound, to whom as yet no Reply hath been made, and yet his booke was printed at Paris by the Kings Printer three yeeres Å¿ince; and alÅ¿o the BiÅ¿hop of RocheÅ¿ter, a learned ProteÅ¿tant, hath out of Catholike grounds conuinced D. Schulckenius his brag, of the cleare and Å¿ound confuting of D. Barclay, to be but vaine. wherefore let Card: Bellarmine firÅ¿t make a cleare and Å¿ound Reply to the aforeÅ¿aid AnÅ¿wers, and then he may haue Å¿ome cauÅ¿e to boaÅ¿t, that he hath clearely and Å¿oundly confuted D. div.head: Chap. 2.

argument.p: Wherein the argument of Card. Bellarmine taken from the authoritie of S. Paul Rom. 12. wee being many are one body in ChriÅ¿t, is examined.

div.p: 1. ANd to begin firÅ¿t with the vnion; Card. Bellarmine bringeth two arguments to proue, that the ciuill and Å¿pirituall power doe make one bodie or common-wealth among ChriÅ¿tians. Pont: cap. 7. that Kings and BiÅ¿hops, Clerkes and Laikes doe not make two common-wealths, but one, to wit, the Church.

2 To this argument I anÅ¿wered in my Num: 83. 89. 165. Apologie, that the meaning of S. Paul in thoÅ¿e places is, that all ChriÅ¿tians, both Kings and BiÅ¿hops, Clerkes and Laikes, as they are by BaptiÅ¿me regenerate in ChriÅ¿t, doe truly, properly, and formally make one bodie, one houÅ¿e, one cittie, one communitie or common-wealth,

4. And whereas Card. Bellarmine affirmeth, that although the temporall and Å¿pirituall power doe make two partiall common-wealths, yet they doe alÅ¿o make one entire and totall common-wealth, which is the Church of ChriÅ¿t, whereof the Pope is the Å¿upreme viÅ¿ible head, and to affirme the contrary, is, Å¿aith he, againÅ¿t the Catholike faith, hee doth heerein both Å¿peake contrarie to his owne principles, and to that which hee knoweth to bee the Catholike faith, and hee muÅ¿t alÅ¿o of neceÅ¿Å¿itie fall into the CanoniÅ¿ts opinion, which he beforeLib. 5. de Ro. Bellarmine in other places doth expreÅ¿Å¿ely affirme, that the Pope as Pope hath onely Å¿pirituall and not temporall power.

5 The Diuines, Å¿aith he,In his book againÅ¿t D. Barclay ca. 12. pag. 137. doe giue to the Pope temporall and Å¿pirituall power onely in the Dominions of the Church, which power in the patrimonie of S. Peter Pope Innocent in cap. per venerabilem doth call a full power; ouer other ChriÅ¿tian Prouinces they doe giue to the Pope onely a Å¿pirituall power, which of it Å¿elfe and properly doth regard Å¿pirituall things, but temporall things it doth regard as they are Å¿ubordained to Å¿pirituall. Now how theÅ¿e two can Å¿tand together, that the Å¿pirituall and temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians doe make one entire and totall body, whereof the Pope is the Å¿upreme viÅ¿ible head, as the body and Å¿oule doe make one man, and yet that the Pope, as Pope, Å¿hall haue no temporall power, which in it Å¿elfe is temporall, but onely Å¿pirituall, athough in Å¿ome caÅ¿es extended to temporall things, Å¿eeing that theÅ¿e two powers doe truely compoÅ¿e the Church of ChriÅ¿t, and conÅ¿equently both of them are truly and really in the Church which they compound, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e in the Pope, in whom all the power of the Church doth reÅ¿ide, I remit to the iudgement of any Å¿enÅ¿ible man.

5. BeÅ¿ides what a more flat contradiction can there be, then this, to Å¿ay, that the ciuill and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians doe compound indeede two partiall, but one entire and totall common-wealth, which is the Church of ChriÅ¿t, or ChriÅ¿tian common-wealth, as hee heere affirmeth,In his Schulckenius cap. 5. pag. 195. and withall, that the Church of ChriÅ¿t

That which my AduerÅ¿arie Widdrington Å¿aith, that the myÅ¿ticall bodie, Church, or Christian common-wealth is compounded of Å¿pirituall authority alone, is true in this Å¿enÅ¿e, that to compound the ChriÅ¿tian common-wealth there is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary a power, which is formally ciuill, but yet there is neceÅ¿Å¿arie a power, which is Å¿o formally Å¿pirituall, that it is alÅ¿o vertually ciuill &c. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e I doe not intend to denie, that the Å¿pirituall or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall power among ChriÅ¿tians may in this Å¿enÅ¿e be called vertually ciuill or temporall, becauÅ¿e it may for the Å¿pirituall good command, and compell Å¿piritually temporall Princes to vÅ¿e their temporall power, for this were onely to contend about words, but that the Church of ChriÅ¿t, whereof the Pope is head, is truely, properly and formally compounded of ciuil and Å¿piritualll power, this I Å¿ay is both vntrue, and alÅ¿o flat contrarie to Card. Bellarmines own grounds; but whether the Å¿piritual power of the church may be called vertually ciuill or temporal, for that it may alÅ¿o conÅ¿traine and puniÅ¿h temporall Princes temporally, or vÅ¿e temporall and ciuill authoritie, in caÅ¿e the temporall Prince for the Å¿pirituall good will not vÅ¿e it, this is the maine queÅ¿tion betwixt mee and Card. Bellarmine.

7. To conclude therefore, this anÅ¿were I doe freely grant: that Kings and BiÅ¿hops, Clearks and Laicks, as by baptiÅ¿me they are regenerate in ChriÅ¿t, doe truely, properly, and formally, make one entire and totall body, which is the Å¿pirituall kingdome, and Church of ChriÅ¿t, whereof the Pope is the Å¿upreme viÅ¿ible head: but I vtterly deny, that this Å¿pirituall

NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e I do not deny, as I obÅ¿erued before but that the temporal & Å¿piritual power, earthly kingdomes, and the Å¿piritual kingdome of ChriÅ¿t, as they are referred to ChriÅ¿t: who, at leaÅ¿twiÅ¿e as God, is the head of them both, doe make one totall body, whereof ChriÅ¿t onely is the head, which may be called the ChriÅ¿tian world, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of ciuill and Å¿pirituall power: but in this manner neither the Pope nor temporall Princes are the head, but onely parts and members of this totall body, as beneath Cap. 1. nu. 4. div.p:
1. THe Å¿econd argument, which Card. Bellarmine bringeth to proue, that the ciuill and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians doe make one totall body, or common-wealth, is taken from the authority of S. Gregory Nazianzene, who compareth the Å¿pirituall and temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians to the Å¿oule and body of man. From which Å¿imilitude Card. Bellarmine argueth in this mannerLib. 5. de Rom. 2. To this argument I anÅ¿wered in my Apologie
num. 139. 140., that from the words of S. Gregorie Nazianzene onely theÅ¿e two things can be gathered. For theÅ¿e bee the expreÅ¿Å¿e wordes, which he vÅ¿ed to the ChriÅ¿tian PreÅ¿ident: For the law of ChriÅ¿t doth make you alÅ¿o Å¿ubiect to my power and authoritie, for we alÅ¿o haue authoritie to command, I add alÅ¿o, a more noble, and more perfect, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be meete, that the Å¿pirit do Å¿ubmit her power to the fleÅ¿h, and heauenly things doe giue place to earthly. Gregorie Nazianzene.

3. Wherefore the vnion of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians is nothing like to the vnion of the body and Å¿oule in man, for that the body is a Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall matter, and the Å¿oule a Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall forme, and therefore being vnited they make one Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall compound, which is called man; who therefore hath in him actually, properly, and formally both body and Å¿oule, as euery compound hath in him the parts, whereof it is compounded, but the ciuill and Å¿pirituall power are not among ChriÅ¿tians vnited, as two parts, compounding really and actually one totall body, which is the Church of ChriÅ¿t, whereof the Pope is head, for that, according to Card. 4. Pardon me, good Reader, that Å¿ometimes I repeate the Å¿ame things Å¿omewhat often; it is not to make my booke the bigger, and to fill it vp with idle repetitions of the Å¿ame things, as my AduerÅ¿aries, to diÅ¿grace me, are pleaÅ¿ed to lay to my charge, not conÅ¿idering that they themÅ¿elues do often times commit the like, but it is onely to cleere thy vnderÅ¿tanding, and to make thee throughly comprehend the difficultie, and in what manner the temporall and Å¿pirituall power are vnited and Å¿ubordained among ChriÅ¿tians, conÅ¿idering that my AduerÅ¿aries, to prooue the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of all temporalls, and to puniÅ¿h temporally by way of conÅ¿traint, doe Å¿o often inculcate this vnion and Å¿ubordination, as a principall ground, whereon the Popes power in temporalls doth depend. Bellarmine, and diÅ¿agreeably to his owne principles, hath laboured to proue, that the temporall and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians doe make one totall body, or common wealth, whereof the Pope is head: now you Å¿hall Å¿ee,

div.head: Chap. 4.

argument.p: Wherein the true Å¿tate of the queÅ¿tion, concerning the Å¿ubiection and Å¿ubordination of the temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians to the Å¿pirituall is propounded, and the different opinions of Catholikes touching this point are rehearÅ¿ed.

div.p:
1. FIrÅ¿t therefore, that you may perceiue the true Å¿tate of the queÅ¿tion, and wherein I doe agree with Card: Bellarmine, and wherein we differ, I doe agree with him in this, that ChriÅ¿tian Princes, in whom the Å¿upreme temporall power doth reÅ¿ide, being the Å¿heepe of ChriÅ¿t, no leÅ¿Å¿e then inferiour perÅ¿ons, are Å¿ubiect to the Å¿upreme viÅ¿ible PaÅ¿tour of the Church of ChriÅ¿t: but the queÅ¿tion is, in what things, and alÅ¿o in what manner they are Å¿ubiect. Secondly, we alÅ¿o agree in this, that ChriÅ¿tian Princes are in Å¿pirituall things, or which doe belong to ChriÅ¿tian faith and Religion, Å¿ubiect not onely to the directiue, or commanding power, but alÅ¿o in Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hments to the coerciue or puniÅ¿hing power of Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that ChriÅ¿tian Princes are not onely bound to obey the command of their Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, in things which doe concerne ChriÅ¿tian faith and religion, but alÅ¿o, if they be diÅ¿obedient, they may with Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hments he puniÅ¿hed and compelled therevnto. Thirdly, we doe alÅ¿o agree in this, that ChriÅ¿tian Princes are bound to obey the commanding power of Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours, not only in thoÅ¿e things, which of their owne nature are
EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall or Å¿pirituall, but alÅ¿o in things temporall, when by accident they become Å¿pirituall; in Å¿o much that a Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tor hath authoritie to command a temporall Prince to vÅ¿e or not vÅ¿e his temporall power, when it is neceÅ¿Å¿arie or hurtfull to Catholike faith and religion, but this is nothing elÅ¿e, then that temporall Princes in things Å¿pirituall (for whether they be per Å¿e, and of their owne nature, or onely by accident Å¿pirituall, it little importeth) are Å¿ubiect to the commanding power of Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, as likewiÅ¿e all temporall cauÅ¿es and crimes, whether of their owne nature, or onely by accident they become temporall, are Å¿ubiect to the commanding and coerciue power of temporall Princes.

2 But the controuerÅ¿ie betwixt me and Card: Bellarmine is concerning two things; the firÅ¿t is, concerning the commanding power, to wit, whether temporall Princes are Å¿ubiect to the commanding power of Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, not onely in things Å¿pirituall, and in temporall, when they become Å¿pirituall, but alÅ¿o in meere temporall things; for this is properly temporall power (taking temporall power in abÅ¿tracto) to be Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall For as a MuÅ¿ician can not truly be Å¿aid to be Å¿ubiect, as he is a MuÅ¿ician, and in all things belonging to MuÅ¿icke, to a PhyÅ¿ition as he is a PhyÅ¿ition, for that MuÅ¿icke is not per Å¿e, and of it owne nature referred to PhyÅ¿icke, and if MuÅ¿icke were per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to PhyÅ¿icke, a MuÅ¿ician, as he is a MuÅ¿ician, and in all things belonging to MuÅ¿icke, Å¿hould be Å¿ubiect to a PhyÅ¿ician, as he is a PhyÅ¿ician: for which cauÅ¿e a Shipwright, as he is a Shipwright, hath intrinÅ¿ecall reference to a Nauigator, for that the Art of making Å¿hips is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature ordayned for nauigation; So alÅ¿o if the temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians be per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall power, it muÅ¿t follow, that temporall
Princes, who are ChriÅ¿tians, are, as they are temporall Princes, and in all things belonging to temporall power, Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours, as they are Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours: And if temporall Princes, who be ChriÅ¿tians, are not Å¿ubiect, as they are temporall Princes, to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, as they are Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, the temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians is not per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall power.

3 The Å¿econd thing, which is in controuerÅ¿ie betwixt me, and Card. Bellarmine, is concerning the coerciue power of Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, to wit, whether temporall Princes are Å¿ubiect to the coerciue power of Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors, (eÅ¿pecially the Pope, who is the Å¿upreme PaÅ¿tour of all ChriÅ¿tians) haue by the inÅ¿titution of ChriÅ¿t authoritie, to depriue temporall Princes of their Kingdomes, to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of all their temporalls, and to puniÅ¿h them temporally, or with all kinde of temporall puniÅ¿hments, in caÅ¿e they will not obey their iuÅ¿t command. And this is the maine point, and principall Å¿cope, at which both the CanoniÅ¿ts, who hold that the Pope hath directly power in temporals in habit, although the vÅ¿e they haue committed to temporall Princes, and alÅ¿o the Diuines, who hold that hee hath onely indirectly, that is, in order to Å¿pirituall good, power in temporalls, doe chiefly aime. Now concerning theÅ¿e two points, there be three different opinions of Catholikes.

4 The firÅ¿t opinion is of the CanoniÅ¿ts, who holding, that the Church of Christ, whereof the Pope is the Å¿upreme viÅ¿ible head, doth conÅ¿iÅ¿t both of temporall and Å¿pirituall power, doe conÅ¿equently hold, that all ChriÅ¿tian Princes, not only as they are ChriÅ¿tians, but alÅ¿o as they are temporall Princes, are in all temporall cauÅ¿es Å¿ubiect to the commanding power, and in all temporall puniÅ¿hments Å¿ubiect alÅ¿o to the
coerciue power of the Pope, whom they make the Å¿upreme, both temporall and Å¿pirituall Monarch of the world, and to haue directly both temporall and Å¿pirituall power, although the vÅ¿e, exerciÅ¿e, and execution of his temporall power, he hath out of the territories of the Church, committed to Secular Princes, as to his Æ²ice-Royes, Vicegerents, or Deputies: and this doctrine Å¿ome Lawyers held to be Å¿o certaine, that they were not afraid to condemne the contrarie as hereticall, for which they are worthily taxed by Coverruvias In Regula, peccatuÌ. 2. part. Relect. Â§. 9. num. 7. of great temeritie; But with this opinion, for that it is commonly reiected by all Diuines, and confuted alÅ¿o by Card: Bellarmine himÅ¿elfeLib. 5. de Rom. Pont. a cap. 2. , I will not at this time intermeddle.

5 The Å¿econd opinion is of many Schoole-Diuines eÅ¿pecially of theÅ¿e later times, who although they Å¿eeme greatly to miÅ¿like the CanoniÅ¿ts opinion, in that the CanoniÅ¿ts hold the Pope, as Pope, to haue directly, not only Å¿pirituall, but alÅ¿o temporall power, and to be both a temporall Monarch, and alÅ¿o a Å¿pirituall Prince and PaÅ¿tour of the whole ChriÅ¿tian world, yet in effect they doe giue as full and ample authoritie to the Pope ouer ChriÅ¿tian Princes, as the CanoniÅ¿ts do; for whatÅ¿oeuer the CanoniÅ¿ts affirme, that the Pope can directly effect by his temporall power, the Å¿ame doe the Diuines affirme, that he can effect indirectly, and in order to Å¿pirituall good by his Å¿pirituall power: And therefore, although they will not grant, that the Pope hath formally temporall power, but only Å¿pirituall, yet they grant, that this Å¿pirituall power of the Pope is virtually, and in effect temporall; and that therefore the Pope by his Å¿pirituall power can in order to Å¿pirituall good depriue temporall Princes of their kingdomes, diÅ¿poÅ¿e of all their temporalls, puniÅ¿h them with all kinde of temporall puniÅ¿hments, and finally whatÅ¿oeuer temporall Princes can by their temporall power doe for the
temporall good, they affirme that the Pope by his Å¿pirituall power can doe for the Å¿pirituall good. Yea Å¿ome of them doe Å¿o extend this Å¿pirituall good and Å¿pirituall harme, taking Å¿pirituall harme, not only for Å¿pirituall crimes, as hereÅ¿ie, ApoÅ¿tacie, and Å¿uch like, but alÅ¿o for all temporall crimes, as are drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e, fornication, and the like, that they giue a more ample power to the Pope, to depriue Princes of their kingdomes, then by temporall lawes is vÅ¿ually granted to temporall Princes to depriue their Å¿ubiects of their lands, who for whoredome, drunkenneÅ¿Å¿e, and many other temporall crimes, can not vÅ¿ually by the lawes of any ChriÅ¿tian kingdome bee depriued of their lands and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions.

6. The third opinion is of many other learned Catholikes both Diuines and Lawyers whom I cited before,Part. 1. per totum. who although they agree with the Å¿econd opinion in this, that the Pope hath power to command temporall Princes in Å¿pirituals, but not in meere temporals, and to puniÅ¿h them with Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hments, when they refuÅ¿e to obey his iuÅ¿t command, yet that the Pope hath any coerciue power (call it Å¿pirituall or temporall, for in effect it is truely temporall) to inflict temporall puniÅ¿hments, to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of temporals for the Å¿pirituall good, or to depriue temporall Princes of their temporall dominions, they vtterly denie, affirming, that onely Excommunication, or Å¿ome Å¿uch like Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hment, is the laÅ¿t, to which the Popes coerciue power can extend: And this their doctrine, which Card. Bellarmine, and Å¿ome few others of his Society, haue preÅ¿umed to condeme as altogether improbable, yea and wholly repugnant to Catholike faith, I haue taken vpon me to maintaine, as neither repugnant to Catholike faith or religion, nor preiudiciall to eternall Å¿aluation, and that therefore it may be defended by any Catholike without any note of hereÅ¿ie, errour or temerity.

7. TheÅ¿e bee the different opinions of Catholikes concerning the Å¿ubiection of the temporall power to the Å¿pirituall, wherby you Å¿ee, that althogh all Catholikes doe grant, that temporall Princes, who are Å¿omtimes called temporall powers, are Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour in things Å¿pirituall, and in temporall when they become Å¿pirituall, yet all doe not grant, that the temporall power it Å¿elfe, euen among ChriÅ¿tians, is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, nor that the Pope, as Pope, hath any coerciue power to conÅ¿traine and puniÅ¿h with temporall puniÅ¿hments, but onely with Å¿pirituall; Neither doth it follow, that becauÅ¿e ChriÅ¿tian Princes are Å¿ubiect to the Pope, therefore they are Å¿ubiect in all things, and in all manner of Å¿ubiection, but onely in that Å¿ort, as ChriÅ¿t hath giuen him power both to command & puniÅ¿h: As children are Å¿ubiect to their Parents, Å¿eruants to their MaÅ¿ters, wiues to their husbands, yet they are not bound to obey them, but in thoÅ¿e things, wherein they haue power to command, nor to be puniÅ¿hed by them, but in that Å¿ort, as the temporall common-wealth, whereof they are members, hath expreÅ¿Å¿ely or couertly giuen them leaue to puniÅ¿h; and the reaÅ¿on is, for that they are not Superiours in an abÅ¿olute and indefinite, but onely in a limited and determinate manner.

8. Now what opinion Card. Bellarmine doth follow, whether of the Diuines, or of the CanoniÅ¿ts, truly I cannot as yet well vnderÅ¿tand. For although he Å¿eeme to diÅ¿allow the CanoniÅ¿ts doctrine, which at large he confuteth in his controuerÅ¿ies, yet to prooue the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of temporals in order to Å¿pirituall good, hee laieth Å¿uch grounds, concerning the vnion and Å¿ubordination of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians, which doe cleerely confirme the CanoniÅ¿ts doctrine. For concerning the vnion of theÅ¿e two powers, hee
affirmeth, as you haue Å¿eene, that the temporall and Å¿pirituall power, the kingdome of ChriÅ¿t, and the kingdomes of this world, when they are ChriÅ¿tian, doe make one totall body, which is the ChriÅ¿tian common-wealth and Church of ChriÅ¿t, whereof the Pope is head; from whence it neceÅ¿Å¿arily followeth, that the Pope, in whom all the power of the Church doth reÅ¿ide, muÅ¿t haue truely, properly and formally both ciuill and Å¿pirituall power, which is the CanoniÅ¿ts opinion, and not onely Å¿pirituall power, which is not formally, but onely vertually ciuill, which the Diuines, and alÅ¿o Card. Bellarmine in places doe affirme. And now concerning the Å¿ubiection and Å¿ubordination of theÅ¿e two powers, he affirmeth, that the temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians, not onely as it is ChriÅ¿tian, but alÅ¿o as it is temporall, is Å¿ubiect to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, as it is EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, or which is all one, that the temporall power it Å¿elfe among ChriÅ¿tians is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall: from whence it cleerely followeth as before I Å¿hewed by the examples of MuÅ¿ike and PhyÅ¿ike, ChriÅ¿tian Princes not onely in Å¿pirituals and in temporals, when they become Å¿pirituals, which is in order to Å¿pirituall good, but alÅ¿o in meere temporall cauÅ¿es, are Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours, which is the CanoniÅ¿ts opinion, and which Card. Bellarmine in other places doth diÅ¿prooue.

9. But how vnÅ¿oundly Card. Bellarmine, and not conformably to his owne grounds laboreth to proue, that the temporall power it Å¿elfe among ChriÅ¿tians, as it is temporall, is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, as it is Å¿pirituall, you Å¿hall anone perceiue. For Å¿ix principall arguments I doe finde in Card. Bellarmine, by which he endeauoureth to conuince, that the temporal power it Å¿elfe among ChriÅ¿tians, as it is temporall, is Å¿ubiect and Å¿ubordained to the Å¿pirituall, as it is Å¿pirituall, or, which I take for all one, that the temporall power
among ChriÅ¿tians is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the inÅ¿titution of ChriÅ¿t, Å¿ubiect and Å¿ubordained to the Å¿pirituall; which arguments of Card. Bellarmine I thinke it fit to examine in this place, together with the Replyes, which he either in his booke againÅ¿t D. Barclay, or in his Schulckenius againÅ¿t mee hath brought to confirme the Å¿ame, that thereby the Reader may fully vnderÅ¿tand, in what manner the temporall power is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, and how Å¿trong or weake a proofe is the Å¿ubiection or Å¿ubordination of theÅ¿e two powers, which is by Mr. Fitzherbert Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be Å¿o inuinÅ¿ible a ground, to conclude from thence, that the Pope, as Pope, hath power, in order to Å¿pirituall good, to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of all temporalls, to depoÅ¿e temporall Princes, and to puniÅ¿h by way of coercion with all kinde of temporall puniÅ¿hments.

div.head: Chap. 5.

argument.p: Wherein is examined Card. Bellarmines firÅ¿t argument taken from the ends of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power.

div.p: 1. THe firÅ¿t argument, which Card. Bellarmine affirmethLib. 5. de Rom Pont. c. 7. to demonÅ¿trate, that the temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians, not only as it is ChriÅ¿tian, but alÅ¿o as it is ciuill, or temporall, is Å¿ubiect to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, as it is EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, is taken from the ends of both the powers. For a temporall end, Å¿aith he, is Å¿ubordained to a Å¿pirituall end, as it is manifeÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e temporall felicitie is not abÅ¿olutely the laÅ¿t end, and therefore it ought to bee referred to eternall felicitie: but it is apparant out of AriÅ¿totle, 1 Ethic. cap. 1. that faculties, or powers are Å¿o Å¿ubordained, as their ends are Å¿ubordained.

2. To this argument I anÅ¿wered in my Apologie Num. 162. & Å¿eq., that not euery temporall end is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature ordained, or Å¿ubordained to a Å¿pirituall end
(Å¿peaking of create ends, and not of God almighty, who is the beginning and end of all things) but it is only by accident, or accidentally by man, who worketh for an end, ordained to a Å¿pirituall end. And therefore although temporall good, or felicity be not abÅ¿olutely the laÅ¿t end of man, yet it is the laÅ¿t end of the temporall power it Å¿elfe, which is in man. For euery power, as it is a power, hath for her laÅ¿t end, her act or worke, as euery Å¿cience hath of it owne nature for her laÅ¿t end the knowledge of her obiect, and euery art the effecting of her work, (as the laÅ¿t end of naturall philoÅ¿ophie is to know the Å¿ecrets of nature, and of PhiÅ¿ike to cure and preÅ¿erue the body from diÅ¿eaÅ¿es) although man himÅ¿elfe, in whom that power, art, or Å¿cience doth reÅ¿ide, doth intend a farther end. Whereupon S. AuÅ¿tin doth well affirme, that the will to Å¿ee hath no other end then Å¿eeing: The will, Å¿aith he,Lib. 11. de Trin. cap. 6.
to Å¿ee hath Å¿eeing for her end, and the will to Å¿ee this thing hath for her end the Å¿eeing of this thing: The will therefore to Å¿ee a skarre doth deÅ¿ire her end, that is, the Å¿eeing of a skarre, and no further doth appertaine to her. Wherefore, as the PhiloÅ¿ophers do diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h betwixt the laÅ¿t end of any art or worke, and the laÅ¿t end of the artificer, or worker, Å¿o we alÅ¿o ought to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h betwixt the laÅ¿t end of the power it Å¿elfe, and of him, in whom the power doth reÅ¿ide. It is called the laÅ¿t end of the worke, for that the worke is in that laÅ¿tly ended, and not the laÅ¿t end of the worker, for that the worker doth not referre all that is his to that end, as a thing to be deÅ¿ired and loued aboue all things.

3. I grant therefore that the end of a ChriÅ¿tian Prince, who hath temporall power, is Å¿pirituall and eternall felicitie, to which ChriÅ¿tians ought to refer all their actions, and the vÅ¿e not only of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, but alÅ¿o of the ciuill power, but withall I affirme, that the laÅ¿t end, which the ciuill power hath
per Å¿e, and of it owne nature, is only temporall peace and quietneÅ¿Å¿e, in the getting and conÅ¿eruing wherof of it owne nature it doth laÅ¿tly reÅ¿t. And therefore for this reaÅ¿on it is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary, that the ciuill power it Å¿elfe be per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubordained to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall, but onely accidentally and by the intention of him, who referreth temporall peace to eternall felicitie in that maner as I haue declared. 10. Neither is it true, that theÅ¿e two powers be of Å¿o diuerÅ¿e a kinde, that they cannot be well compared to two Å¿houlders, for both of them are powers, and in that reÅ¿pect of the Å¿ame kinde, and as powers they are compared to two Å¿houlders. Barclay muÅ¿t bee taxed of hereÅ¿ie, for comparing the temporall and Å¿pirituall power in the Church, or ChriÅ¿tian world (for now the Church and ChriÅ¿tian world which conÅ¿iÅ¿teth of both powers, is taken for all one) to two Å¿houlders, and for affirming, that ChriÅ¿t only is the chiefe celeÅ¿tial and inviÅ¿ible head of both theÅ¿e powers, and that Kings and Popes are two miniÅ¿teriall heads thereof (although both of them are alÅ¿o principall in their owne kinde, and in the nature of a viÅ¿ible head) then muÅ¿t Hugo de S.
