Then muÅ¿t Thomas WaldenÅ¿is our learned Country-man be taxed of hereÅ¿ie, when after hee had related the aforeÅ¿aid words of Hugo, hee concludeth thusLib. 2. doctr. fid. art. 3. ca. 78 : Behold two powers, and two heads of power: and beneath LikewiÅ¿e, Å¿aith he, neither Kingly power, which by the ring of faith or fidelitie is eÅ¿pouÅ¿ed to the kingdome,

ChryÅ¿oÅ¿tome, Theophylact, and Oecumenius bee taxed of hereÅ¿ie, when they affirmeAd Rom. 13. , That whoÅ¿oeuer hee bee, whether he be a Monke, a PrieÅ¿t, or an ApoÅ¿tle, he is according to S. Paul Å¿ubiect to temporall Princes; as likewiÅ¿e Pope Pelagius the firÅ¿t, who affirmethApud. Bininum tom. 2. Concil. pag. 633 , That Popes alÅ¿o according to the command of holy Scriptures were Å¿ubiect to Kings.

15. Then muÅ¿t the ancient GloÅ¿Å¿e of the Canon Law In cap. Adrianus diÅ¿t. 63. , related and approued by Cardinall CuÅ¿anus
Lib. 3. de Concord. Cath. cap. 3., (which GloÅ¿Å¿e Card. Bellarmine In Tract. coÌtr. Barcl. ca. 13. 16 , with Å¿mall reÅ¿pect to antiquity, doth Å¿hamefully call a doting old woman, and which perchance is aboliÅ¿hed for ouermuch old age) be taxed of hereÅ¿ie, affirming, That as the Pope is Father of the Emperour in Å¿pirituall â¢ ; Å¿o the Emperour is the Popes Father in temporalls. ChriÅ¿tiana cap. 2. , That the Pope, and the Emperour are not in the Church as two Å¿ubordinate Iudges, Å¿o that one receiueth his iuriÅ¿diction from the other: but they are as two Gouernours, who are the MiniÅ¿ters of one God deputed to diuerÅ¿e offices, Å¿o that the

16 But to theÅ¿e and Å¿uch like pittifull Å¿hifts and extremities are Å¿ometimes driuen men otherwiÅ¿e very learned, when they are not afraid by clamours, Å¿landers, and threatnings, rather then by force of reaÅ¿on, to thruÅ¿t vpon the ChriÅ¿tian world their owne vncertaine opinions for infallible grounds of the Catholike faith, and rather then they will Å¿eeme to haue been too raÅ¿h in their CenÅ¿ures, or not Å¿o Å¿ound in their iudgements, they care not, although with palpable Å¿ophiÅ¿mes, Å¿o that they may in regard of their authoritie any way blinde the eyes of the vnlearned Reader with their cunning and ambiguous Å¿peeches, to maintaine what they haue once begun, and with no Å¿mall Å¿candall to Catholike religion, and great hurt to their owne Å¿oules, and which alÅ¿o in the end will turne to their owne diÅ¿credit, to impeach thoÅ¿e Catholikes of diÅ¿obedience, hereÅ¿ie, or errour, who Å¿hall impugne their new pretended faith and doctrine, as being no point of the true, ancient, Catholike, and ApoÅ¿tolike faith, nor grounded vpon any one certaine authoritie or argument taken either from the teÅ¿timonie of holy Scriptures, ancient Fathers, decrees of Councells, practiÅ¿e of the primitiue Church, or any one Theologicall reaÅ¿on, wherevpon any one of the moÅ¿t learnedÅ¿t of them all dare rely.

But truth and plaine dealing in the end will preuaile, neither will violence, but reaÅ¿on Å¿atisfie mens vnderÅ¿tandings, and this their violent, Å¿huffling, and vnÅ¿incere proceeding doth plainly Å¿hew, that they diÅ¿truÅ¿t their cauÅ¿e. div.head: Chap. 7.

argument.p: Wherein the third argument, which is taken from the changing of temporall gouernment, when it hindereth the Å¿pirituall good, is examined.

div.p:
1. THe third argument, which Card. Bellarmine bringeth to proue, that the ciuill power among ChriÅ¿tians, not only as it is ChriÅ¿tian, but alÅ¿o as it is ciuill, is Å¿ubiect, and Å¿ubordained to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall as it is EccleÅ¿iasticall, is this: Thirdly, Å¿aith he,Lib. 5. de Rom: Pont. cap: 7.
if the temporall gouernment hinder the Å¿pirituall good, the Prince, according to the opinion of all men, is bound to change that manner of gouernment, euen with the hinderance of temporall good, therefore it is a Å¿igne that the temporall power is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall.

2 Neither doth he Å¿atisfie, that Å¿hould anÅ¿wer, that a Prince is bound to change that manner of his gouernment, not for the Å¿ubordination to the Å¿pirituall power, but onely for order of charitie, by which wee are bound to preferre greater goods before loÅ¿Å¿er. For in regard of the order of charitie, one common-wealth is not bound to Å¿uffer detriment, that an other common-wealth more noble doe not Å¿uffer the like detriment. And one priuate man, who is bound to giue all his goods for the conÅ¿eruation of his owne common-wealth, is not bound to doe the like for an other common-wealth, although the more noble. Seeing therefore that the temporall common-wealth is bound to Å¿uffer detriment for the Å¿piritual common-weatlh, it is a Å¿igne that they are not two diuerÅ¿e common-wealths, but parts of one and the Å¿ame common-wealth, and one Å¿ubiect to the other.

3. Neither alÅ¿o is it of force, if one Å¿hould Å¿ay, that a temporall Prince is bound to Å¿uffer detriment for the Å¿pirituall good, not in regard of any Å¿ubiection of the temporall commonwealth to the Å¿pirituall common wealth, but becauÅ¿e
otherwiÅ¿e he Å¿hould hurt his Å¿ubiects, to whom it is hurtfull to looÅ¿e Å¿piritualls for temporalls. For although thoÅ¿e men, who are not his Å¿ubiects, but are of an other kingdome, Å¿hould Å¿uffer any notable hurt in Å¿piritualls, for the gouernment in temporalls of Å¿ome ChriÅ¿tian King, he is bound to change his manner of gouernment, whereof no other reaÅ¿on can be giuen, but that they are members of the Å¿ame body, and one Å¿ubiect to the other.

4. By this argument Card. Bellarmine, as you Å¿ee, laboureth to proue two things, the one is, that not only Lay-men, and Cleargie-men doe make one totall body, which is the Church of ChriÅ¿t, whereof the Pope is head, for of this no Catholike maketh any doubt, but alÅ¿o that the temporall & Å¿pirituall power themÅ¿elues, or which is all one, the temporall and Å¿pirituall common wealth, as they conÅ¿iÅ¿t of temporall and Å¿pirituall power, are parts or this totall body called the Church of ChriÅ¿t, whereof the Pope is the Å¿upreme viÅ¿ible head. The Å¿econd is, that not only temporall Princes are in Å¿pirituals Å¿ubiect to the Å¿upreme Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour, but alÅ¿o, that the temporall power itÅ¿elfe, as it is temporall, is among ChriÅ¿tians Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall power, as it is Å¿pirituall, and conÅ¿equently, that temporall Princes not onely in Å¿piritualls, but alÅ¿o in all temporalls are Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall power. But neither of theÅ¿e can bee rightly concluded from this argument, as I Å¿hewed in my Apologie Num. 160. & Å¿eq., where I denied the conÅ¿equence of this third argument, Å¿peaking of Å¿ubiection and Å¿ubordination per Å¿e, and of it owne nature. For if temporall gouernment doe hinder Å¿pirituall good, the temporall Prince is bound to change that manner of gouernment euen with detriment of temporall good, not for that the temporall power is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, as though of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power were made formally one politike body, but for both the reaÅ¿ons alledged by
Card. Bellarmine, which he did not Å¿ufficiently confute in his Replyes.

p.q: 5. The firÅ¿t reaÅ¿on is for the order of charitie, by which we are bound to prefer greater goods before leÅ¿Å¿er. To the Reply, which Card. Bellarmine made to the contrarie, I anÅ¿wered thus, that although for the order of charity one common wealth is not bound to Å¿uffer detriment, that an other common wealth more noble doe not Å¿uffer the like detriment, yet in caÅ¿e that both common wealths bee Å¿ubiect to one Prince, or that the Prince of the leÅ¿Å¿e noble coÌmon wealth be alÅ¿o a Å¿ubiect of the more noble, then that Prince is bound for order of charitie, all other things being alike, to preferre the more noble common-wealth before the leÅ¿Å¿e noble. And although one priuate man, who is bound to giue all his goods for the conÅ¿eruation of his owne common-wealth, bee not bound to doe the like for an other common-wealth, although the more noble, yet in caÅ¿e that the Å¿ame priuate man Å¿hould at the Å¿ame time bee a Citizen of both common-wealths, if he be bound to giue all his goods for the conÅ¿eruation of the leÅ¿Å¿e noble common wealth, whereof he is a Citizen, he is much more bound for the Å¿ame order of charitie, to giue all his goods for the conÅ¿eruation of the more noble common wealth, to which alÅ¿o he is Å¿ubiect. And this is the very caÅ¿e in this preÅ¿ent queÅ¿tion. For the Å¿pirituall and ciuill power, and the common wealths which they compound, are Å¿o vnited and connected among ChriÅ¿tians, that euery ChriÅ¿tian is a Citizen of both common wealths, and both common wealths may be Å¿ubiect to the Å¿ame Prince, as appeareth in the Pope, who is the Å¿pirituall Prince or PaÅ¿tour of the whole ChriÅ¿tian world, and alÅ¿o a temporall Prince of Å¿ome Prouinces thereof.

6. The Å¿econd reaÅ¿on, for which a temporall Prince is bound to change the manner of his gouernment
in the aforeÅ¿aid caÅ¿e, is, for that otherwiÅ¿e he Å¿hould hurt his Å¿ubiects, to whom it is hurtfull to looÅ¿e greater goods for the leÅ¿Å¿er, that is Å¿pirituall goods for temporall. To the Reply, which Card. Bellarmine made to the contrary, I anÅ¿wered, that the reaÅ¿on wherefore a temporall Prince is bound to change his manner of gouernment, if it be greatly hurtfull to the Å¿pirituall good not only of his owne Å¿ubiects, but alÅ¿o of the Å¿ubiects of another Kingdome, is not for that the temporall power is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, or for that both of them are parts of one, and the Å¿ame totall common wealth, but becauÅ¿e both the King, and alÅ¿o thoÅ¿e Å¿ubiects of an other temporall kingdome, are alÅ¿o members of the Å¿ame myÅ¿ticall body of ChriÅ¿t, and Cittizens of the Å¿ame Å¿pirituall Kingdome, and therefore that King leaÅ¿t that he Å¿hould greatly preiudice in Å¿piritualls the kingdome of ChriÅ¿t, whereof he is a Citizen, by his temporall gouernment, is bound to change that manner of gouernment. Thus I anÅ¿wered in my Apologie.

div.p:
7. Now you Å¿hall Å¿ee how cunningly D. Schulckenius would Å¿hift of this anÅ¿were. To the firÅ¿t part of my anÅ¿were he replyeth thus: Pag. 339. H â¢ ere I Å¿ee nothing that needeth any anÅ¿were Å¿auing that [as though of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power were formally made one politike body] For my AduerÅ¿ary Widdrington doth grant the antecedentâª of Card. Bellarmines argument, and denieth the conÅ¿equence, and for this cauÅ¿e he doth deny it, for that of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power is not made formally one politike body, and therefore one power is not per Å¿e Å¿ubiect to the other. But what man that is well in his wits did euer Å¿ay, that of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power is made formally one politike body? For although Cleargie men are Cittizens of the ciuill common wealth, as they liue together with the Citizens of that common wealth, and do buy, Å¿ell, and doe other things according
to the lawes of that common-wealth, yet becauÅ¿e they are exempted from the power of the politike Prince, and doe obÅ¿erue his lawes not by force of the law, but by force of reaÅ¿on, they cannot properly and formally, but onely materially be called parts of the ciuill common-wealth.

8. Adde alÅ¿o that if the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall and ciuill power Å¿hould make one politike body, the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Å¿hould either be Å¿uperiour, or Å¿ubiect to the ciuill, Å¿uperiour it could not be, for that the King is head of the politike body, neither could it be Å¿ubiect, for that a Å¿uperiour power ought not to be Å¿ubiect to an inferiour. And beÅ¿ides (as it hath beene Å¿ayd) Cleargie men are exempted from the power of a politike Prince, and therefore the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall and ciuill power doe not make properly and formally one politike body. But my AduerÅ¿arie doth faine abÅ¿urd opinions, which hee may refell. That which Card. Bellarmine Å¿aith, is, that the Å¿pirituall and temporall power, that is, BiÅ¿hops, Kings, and their Å¿ubiects, Clerkes and Laikes doe make one Church, one ChriÅ¿tian common-wealth, one people, one kingdome, or myÅ¿ticall body of ChriÅ¿t, wherein all things are well ordered and diÅ¿poÅ¿ed, and therefore Å¿uperiour things doe rule inferiour things, and inferiour things are Å¿ubiect to Å¿uperiour things. Let my AduerÅ¿arie Widdrington ouerthrow this, and then let him deny the conÅ¿equence of Card. Bellarmines argument. Thus D. Schulckenius.

9. But how vnÅ¿ound, cunning, and inÅ¿ufficient, is this Reply of D. Schulckenius, and alÅ¿o repugnant to his owne grounds, you Å¿hall preÅ¿ently perceiue. And firÅ¿t when I denied, that the Å¿pirituall and temporall power doe make formally one politike body, by a politike body I did not vnderÅ¿tand, as it diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed and contra-diuided to a Å¿pirituall body, but as it is diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed from a naturall body, and comprehendeth in generall all politike gouernments, whether they be temporall, Å¿pirituall, or mixt, in which Å¿enÅ¿e not onely earthly kingdomes compounded of temporall power, but
alÅ¿o the Å¿pirituall kingdome, myÅ¿ticall body or Church of ChriÅ¿t conÅ¿iÅ¿ting onely of Å¿pirituall power is a politike body. Wherefore by the name of a politike body I vnderÅ¿tood a common-wealth in generall, whether it were temporall, Å¿pirituall, or mixt of both, as any man, who is not deÅ¿irous to cauill, may eaÅ¿ily perceiue by all thoÅ¿e anÅ¿wers and aÅ¿Å¿ertions, which I did Å¿o often inculcate concerning the vnion and coniunction of theÅ¿e two powers. So that my meaning in that place onely was to deny, that the temporall and Å¿pirituall power, as they are referred to the viÅ¿ible heads and Å¿ubiects of both powers, doe make formally one totall common-wealth, but onely materially, for that the Å¿ame ChriÅ¿tian men, who haue temporall power or temporall Å¿ubiection, doe make one Å¿pirituall Kingdome or Church of ChriÅ¿t, but not formally, as they haue temporall power, or temporall Å¿ubiection, for Å¿o they make onely temporall and earthly kingdomes, but formally as they haue temporall and Å¿pirituall power, temporall and Å¿pirituall Å¿ubiection, and are referred to the viÅ¿ible heads thereof, they make two totall bodies or common-wealths, as before I haue declared more at large.

10. Secondly, although it be true, that temporall and Å¿pirituall power, that is, Kings and BiÅ¿hops, Clerks and Laikes, as D. Schulckenius expoundeth thoÅ¿e words (which neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e is a very improper acception of thoÅ¿e words, for that temporall and Å¿pirituall power in abÅ¿tracto doth Å¿ignifie Kings and BiÅ¿hops, Clerkes and Laikes as they haue temporall and Å¿pirituall power) doe make one Church, one ChriÅ¿tian common-wealth, one people, one kingdome or myÅ¿ticall body of ChriÅ¿t, yet this was not all that, which Card. Bellarmine affirmed, for Card. Bellarmine affirmed another thing, which I pretended to impugne, and which D. Schulckenius cunningly concealeth, to wit, that Kings and BiÅ¿hops, Clerkes and Laikes doe not make two common-wealths,

24 But this Reply of D. Schulckenius is as fraudulent, and inÅ¿ufficient, as the former: for in effect it is only a repetition of his former Reply, to which I haue already anÅ¿wered, beÅ¿ides Å¿ome fraudulent dealing, which he hath vÅ¿ed herein. argument.p: Wherein is examined the fourth argument, taken from the authoritie of S. Gregorie Nazianzene, comparing the temporall and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians, to the body and Å¿oule in man.

div.p: 1. THE fourth argument, which Card. Bellarmine bringeth to prooue this Å¿ubiection of of the temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians, to the Å¿pirituall power of the Church, is taken from the authoritie of S. Gregorie Nazianzene, who compareth the temporall and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians to the body and Å¿oule in man: yea, and alÅ¿o affirmeth, that temporall MagiÅ¿trates are Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors. And this Å¿imilitude doth Å¿o greatly pleaÅ¿e Card. Bellarmines conceit, that when hee hath any fit occaÅ¿ion, he Å¿pareth not to inculcate it, as a very Å¿trong argument, and fit Å¿imilitude to proue, that the temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians is per Å¿e, and of it owne nature Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, as the body in man is per Å¿e, Å¿ubiect to the Å¿oule. For as the Å¿pirit and fleÅ¿h, Å¿aith heLib. 5. de RoÌ. pont. cap. 6. , are in man, Å¿o are the Å¿pirituall and temporall power in the Church. The Å¿pirit hath vnderÅ¿tanding and wil, and acts and proportionate obiects, and for her end the health and perfection of the Å¿oule. 2 Whereby it is manifeÅ¿t, that neither of them is preciÅ¿ely for the other. The fl â¢ Å¿h alÅ¿o is found vnited to the Å¿pirit in man, where becauÅ¿e they make one perÅ¿on, they haue neceÅ¿Å¿arily Å¿ubordination and connexion. For the fleÅ¿h is Å¿ubiect, the Å¿pirit is Å¿uperiour, and although the Å¿pirit doth not intermeddle hir Å¿elfe with the actions of the fleÅ¿h, but doth Å¿uffer the fleÅ¿h to exerciÅ¿e all hir actions, as Å¿hee doth exerciÅ¿e in beaÅ¿ts, yet when they doe hurt the end of the Å¿pirit, the Å¿pirit doth command the fleÅ¿h, and doth puniÅ¿h hir, and if it be needfull, doth appoint faÅ¿tings, and alÅ¿o other afflictions, euen with Å¿ome detriment, and weakning of the bodie, and doth compell the tongue not to Å¿peake, the eyes not to Å¿ee, &c. In like manner if any action of the fleÅ¿h, yea and death it Å¿elfe, be neceÅ¿Å¿arie to obtaine the end of the Å¿pirit, the Å¿pirit hath power to command the fleÅ¿h to expoÅ¿e hir Å¿elfe and all hirs, as wee Å¿ee in Martyrs.

3 Euen Å¿o the ciuill power hath hir Princes, lawes, iudgements &c. and likewiÅ¿e the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall hath hir BiÅ¿hops, Canons, iudgements. The ciuill hath for hir end temporall peace, the Å¿pirituall euerlaÅ¿ting Å¿aluation. They are Å¿ometimes found Å¿eparated, as long Å¿ince in the time of the ApoÅ¿tles, Å¿ometimes vnited as now. 4 Thus you Å¿ee, that Card: Bellarmine hath made here a plauÅ¿ible diÅ¿courÅ¿e, but truly more beÅ¿eeming, as I will moÅ¿t clearely convince, a cunning oratour, who with fine, and wittie conceipts Å¿eeketh

For neither is the temporall and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians well compared to the body, and Å¿oule of man, either in vnion, or in Å¿ubiection, and beÅ¿ides, although it were in all things a fit Å¿imilitude, yet it doth not any way proue that, which Card. 5 For firÅ¿t, as I Å¿hewed before Cap. 2. 3. out of Card Bellarmines owne grounds, the temporall and Å¿pirituall power, as they are referred to their viÅ¿ible heads here on earth, doe not make properly and formally one totall bodie, or common-wealth, which is the Å¿pirituall kingdome, or Church of ChriÅ¿t, but they doe make properly, and formally two totall bodies, or common wealths, to wit, earthly kingdomes, or a temporall, and ciuill bodie, whereof the King is head, as D. Schulckenius alÅ¿o affirmeth, Pag. 203. is onely compounded of Å¿pirituall power. Seeing therefore, that the reaÅ¿on why Card. Bellarmine affirmeth, that temporall power among ChriÅ¿tians is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, is for that they do make one totall bodie, or common-wealth, as the bodie and Å¿oule doe make one man, and conÅ¿equently the temporall power muÅ¿t be Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, as the bodie is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿oule of man, and as I haue clearely proued, there is no Å¿uch vnion of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power to make one totall bodie conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of both powers, which is the Å¿pirituall kingdome or Church of CHRIST, it is manifeÅ¿t, that

6 Secondly, although I doe willingly grant, as you haue Å¿eene before Cap. 1., that not onely the temporall and Å¿pirituall power among ChriÅ¿tians, as they are referred not to their viÅ¿ible heads here on earth, but to CHRIST the inviÅ¿ible head of them both, doe make one totall bodie, or common-wealth, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting actually of both powers, which may bee called the ChriÅ¿tian world (in which Å¿enÅ¿e the ChriÅ¿tian common wealth is vÅ¿ually taken, but the Church of CHRIST, and eÅ¿pecially the Å¿pirituall kingdome of CHRIST is Å¿eldome taken in that Å¿enÅ¿e) but alÅ¿o the whole world, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of ChriÅ¿tians, and Infidells, may in that manner be called one totall bodie, whereof CHRIST, at leaÅ¿t wiÅ¿e, as he is GOD, is the inviÅ¿ible, and celeÅ¿tiall head, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e this Å¿imilitude of the Å¿oule and bodie vnited in one man doth nothing auaile to proue the Å¿ubiection of the temporall power to the Å¿pirituall, both vnited in one totall bodie, whereof CHRIST onely, and no earthly creature is the head. For the reaÅ¿on, why the bodie in man is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿oule, is becauÅ¿e the bodie and Å¿oule doe make one eÅ¿Å¿entiall compound, as the PhiloÅ¿ophers doe call it, whereof the bodie is the matter, and the Å¿oule is the forme, and conÅ¿equently the bodie muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿itie, and by a naturall Å¿equele, be Å¿ubiect to the Å¿oule, as euery matter is per Å¿e and of it own nature Å¿ubiect to the form, with which it maketh one eÅ¿Å¿entiall compound, but the temporal & Å¿piritual power or earthly Kingdomes, and the Å¿pirituall kingdome of ChriÅ¿t, as they make one totall body, wherof ChriÅ¿t onely is the head, doe not make one eÅ¿Å¿entiall compound, whereof one is as the matter, and the other
as the forme, but they doe make one integrall compound, as the PhiloÅ¿ophers doe call it, in that manner as the bodie of man is compounded of eyes, eares, tongue, hands, feete, which are called by the PhiloÅ¿ophers integrall, and not eÅ¿Å¿entiall parts of mans bodie; but in an integrall compound, it is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary, as I Å¿hewed before Cap. 6. nu: 10., that one part be Å¿ubiect to another, although all muÅ¿t be Å¿ubiect to the head, as it is apparant in the eyes, eares, tongue, hands, and feet of mans bodie, whereof none is Å¿ubiect one to the other, although all be Å¿ubiect to the head. Seeing therefore that the temporall and Å¿pirituall power are onely integrall parts of the totall body, whereof ChriÅ¿t onely is the head, it is euident that from hence no probable argument can be drawne to proue, that the temporall power is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, but that both of them are vnited and Å¿ubiect to ChriÅ¿t the inuiÅ¿ible head of them both.

7. Thirdly, although I Å¿hould alÅ¿o grant, that this were a fit Å¿imilitude in all things, and that the temporall power is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall in that manner as the body is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿oule of man, yet this manner of Å¿ubiection would nothing auaile to proue, that the Å¿pirituall power could either directly, or indirectly diÅ¿poÅ¿e of temporalls, depriue temporall Princes of their temporall liues or dominions, vÅ¿e temporall puniÅ¿hments, or exerciÅ¿e any temporall action, but it is rather a very fit Å¿imilitude to conuince the flat contrary. For as I will eaÅ¿ily grant, that the Å¿oule hath power to command, or forbid the body to exerciÅ¿e any corporall action, when it is neceÅ¿Å¿arie or hurtfull to the end not onely of the Å¿oule but alÅ¿o of the body, (which laÅ¿t clauÅ¿e Card. Bellarmine cunningly omitteth, for that it fauoureth, as you Å¿hall Å¿ee, the Popes direct power to command temporalls) as to Å¿ee, to heare, to Å¿peake, and Å¿uch like actions, which are Å¿ubiect to the command of mans will, I Å¿ay, which are Å¿ubiect
to the command of mans will, for that there be many corporall actions, which are not in the power of mans will to command, as are all the actions of the nutritiue, vegetatiue and generatiue powers; But if the body by any let, or hinderance can not, or (if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible) would not doe that corporall action, which the Å¿oule would willingly haue the body to doe, as to Å¿ee, to heare, to Å¿peake, or to goe, the Å¿oule hath no power of her Å¿elfe either directly, or indirectly, that is, either for the good of the body, or for the good of the Å¿oule, to do that corporall action, as to Å¿ee, heare, Å¿peake, or goe, without the concurrence of the body it Å¿elfe.

8. Neither hath the Å¿oule any power to inflict any corporal puniÅ¿hment by way of coercion or conÅ¿traint, that is, to puniÅ¿h actually with corporall puniÅ¿hment any member of the body without the concurrence of Å¿ome one or other member thereof, but onely by the way of command, that is, to command Å¿ome one member to puniÅ¿h it Å¿elfe; or an other member, as the hands, feete, or head, to put themÅ¿elues into fire or water, or the hands, to whip the Å¿houlders, to cloÅ¿e thy eye-lids, to Å¿top the eares, not to put meate into the mouth, and Å¿uch like, which if the bodily member by any let, or hinderance can not, or, if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible, would not doe, the Å¿oule hath done all that is in her power to doe, for that Å¿he cannot of her Å¿elfe doe any corporall action, without the concurrence of Å¿ome corporall member, but the moÅ¿t that Å¿he can doe concerning any corporall action or puniÅ¿hment, is to command the body to concurre with her to the doing of that corporall action, or puniÅ¿hment. I Å¿aid [if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible] for that there is Å¿uch a naturall, neceÅ¿Å¿arie, and intrinÅ¿ecall Å¿ubiection of the body to the Å¿oule, that the body cannot reÅ¿iÅ¿t the effectuall command of the Å¿oule in thoÅ¿e things which are Å¿ubiect to her command, and therefore I Å¿aid, that if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible,

In the like manner I will eaÅ¿ily grant, that the temporall power is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, or rather that temporall Princes, who haue temporall power, but not as they haue temporall power, are Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours, who haue Å¿pirituall power, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that the Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour hath power to command the temporall Prince to do thoÅ¿e temporal actions belonging to his temporall power, which are neceÅ¿Å¿arie to the end of the Å¿pirituall power, and to forbid him thoÅ¿e actions belonging to his temporall power, which are repugnant to the end of the Å¿pirituall power, which is eternall Å¿aluation, which if hee refuÅ¿e to doe, and will not obey the command of the Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour, the Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour can not by vertue only of his Å¿pirituall power exerciÅ¿e any temporall; or ciuill action, belonging to the temporall, or ciuill power, without the conÅ¿ent, or concurrance of the temporall power: Neither can the Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tor inflict any temporall, or ciuill puniÅ¿hment by way of coercion, conÅ¿traint, or compulÅ¿ion, that is, puniÅ¿h actually with any temporall, or ciuill puniÅ¿hment without the conÅ¿ent, & concurrance of the temporall, or ciuill power, but only by the way of command, that is, he hath power to command the temporall Prince, who only hath Å¿upreme temporall authoritie, to puniÅ¿h himÅ¿elfe, or his Å¿ubiects with temporall, or ciuill
puniÅ¿hments, if they vÅ¿e their temporals to the hurt? and preiudice of the Å¿pirituall power, or the end therof? although I doe willingly grant, that the Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour hath power to puniÅ¿h the temporall Prince, or his Å¿ubiects, with Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hments, not onely by the way of command, but alÅ¿o of coercion and conÅ¿traint that is, to puniÅ¿h them actually, whether they will or no, with Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hments, when they Å¿hall refuÅ¿e to obey his iuÅ¿t command, for that this manner of puniÅ¿hing by way of coercion doth not exceede the limits of the Å¿pirituall coerciue power.

10. Now if my AduerÅ¿aries demand or mee, why the Å¿pirituall power may of her Å¿elfe command temporall actions, and yet neither directly, nor indirectly, that is, neither for temporall, nor Å¿pirituall good, exerciÅ¿e temporall actions, may command ciuill puniÅ¿hments, when they are neceÅ¿Å¿arie to the end of the Å¿pirituall power, and yet neither directly, nor indirectly puniÅ¿h actually with ciuill puniÅ¿hments without the concurrance of the Å¿pirituall power, I anÅ¿wer them by their owne Å¿imilitude, which pleaÅ¿eth them Å¿o much; for the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on, that the Å¿oule hath power of her Å¿elfe to command bodily actions, and yet neither directly, nor indirectly, that is, neither for the good of the body, nor of the Å¿oule, to doe of her Å¿elfe alone any bodily action, hath power to command bodily puniÅ¿hments, and yet of her Å¿elfe hath not power to inflict any bodily puniÅ¿hment, without the concurrance of the bodie it Å¿elfe. And thus you Å¿ee, that this Å¿imilitude, of which Card. Schulckenius neither dealeth truely nor Å¿incerely, and both deludeth his Reader, and alÅ¿o wrongeth mee, in affirming, that to bee my doctrine, which I expreÅ¿Å¿ely impugne, and that to be the foundation of my opinion (which hee is pleaÅ¿ed to call an errour) which I in expreÅ¿Å¿e words, and that oftentimes haue denied.

21. For as I doe willingly grant, that although a temporall Prince hath power to command, and with temporall puniÅ¿hments to compell, if neede require, his temporall Å¿ubiects to make, and Å¿weare an expreÅ¿Å¿e promiÅ¿e of that true faith, loyaltie and temporall allegeance, which by the Law of God and nature they doe owe to their lawfull Prince, yet I doe not affirme, that a temporalll Prince hath power to conÅ¿traine his rebellious Å¿ubiects by vertue onely of the promiÅ¿e, which they haue made, but by vertue of his Å¿upreme temporall power which hee hath, as hee is a Å¿upreme temporall Prince by the Law of God and nature; So alÅ¿o I do willingly grant, that although the Pope hath power to command, and with Å¿pirituall puniÅ¿hments to compell, if neede require, all ChriÅ¿tian Princes and people to make and Å¿weare an expreÅ¿Å¿e promiÅ¿e of that the true faith, loyalty and Å¿pirituall allegeance, which as they are ChriÅ¿tians and members of the myÅ¿ticall body of ChriÅ¿t, they doe owe by the Law of God to the Å¿upreme Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour and viÅ¿ible head of this myÅ¿ticall bodie and Church of ChriÅ¿t, and the Emperour at his coronation taketh Å¿uch an oath, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e I doe not affirme, that the Pope hath power to conÅ¿traine and puniÅ¿h diÅ¿obedient Princes, and people by vertue onely of the promiÅ¿e, which they haue
made to the Pope of their Å¿pirituall obedience, but by vertue of his Å¿upreme Å¿pirituall power, which he hath by the Law of God, and his PaÅ¿torall authority giuen to him by our Sauiour ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us.

32. True it is, that the Reader might the better vnderÅ¿tand, that to command one to vÅ¿e a temporall thing, and to vÅ¿e it himÅ¿elfe, to command one to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of temporals, and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of them himÅ¿elfe, are very different things, and that the one doth not neceÅ¿Å¿arily follow from the other, I brought a familiar example of one, who either, by promiÅ¿e, or by Å¿ome other obligation (and yet D. argument.p: Wherein the Å¿imilitude of Pope Innocent the third, who compareth the Å¿pirituall and temporall power to the Sun & Moone, is examined.

div.p: 1. THe Å¿ixt, and laÅ¿t argument, which Card. Bellarmine bringth to proue the Å¿biection of the temporall power to the Å¿pirituall, is taken from the authority of Pope Innocent the third, who in cap. 2. But firÅ¿t this Å¿imilitude doth not proue, that the temporall power it Å¿elfe is Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall, or, which is all one, that a temporall King is Å¿ubiect to the Pope in reÅ¿pect of his temporall power, which he doth not receiue from the Pope, but in reÅ¿pect of the light of faith, which a temporall King receiueth from the Å¿pirituall power. 3. Secondly, that, which Card. Bellarmine affirmeth, that the Pope receiueth nothing from temporall Princes is very vntrue, and therefore in this point alÅ¿o that part of the Å¿imilitude is not fitly applyed. For the Pope hath receiued from temporall Princes all his temporall dominion, iuriÅ¿diction, and temporall Å¿word, and the whole patrimonie of S. 4. Whereupon well Å¿ayd S. AmbroÅ¿e, Lib. 10. in LucaÌ. cap. 20.

See alÅ¿o aboue Cap. 6. nu. 13. 14. 15. & cap. 7. nu. 12. 13. many other Catholike Authours who doe affirme that Cleargy men are Å¿ubiect to the directiue power of temporall Princes. 40 Wherefore if wee reÅ¿pect the power it Å¿elfe, and the vertue of legall or morall iuÅ¿tice, a temporall Prince hath full, ample, and Å¿upreme royall power and authority ouer Clergy men, notwithÅ¿tanding that his Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tor Å¿hould for iuÅ¿t cauÅ¿e command him not to exerciÅ¿e his Regall power vpon the perÅ¿ons of Clergie men, who doe offend his lawes: but if wee reÅ¿pect rhe vÅ¿e and execution of the power, and the vertue of religion, the vÅ¿e indeed of his power in the
aforeÅ¿aid caÅ¿e is Å¿o limited by the lawfull command of the Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tor, that the Prince vÅ¿ing his power ouer Clergy men, Å¿inneth againÅ¿t Religion, for that hee diÅ¿obeyeth the lawfull command of his Å¿pirituall Superiour, which was impoÅ¿ed for the motiue of religion, but not againÅ¿t iuÅ¿tice for that hee doth not excerciÅ¿e his Regall power but vpon thoÅ¿e who are his Subiects, and doe owe vnto him true loyalty and temporall obedience.

41 And truely if the aforeÅ¿aid obiection were of force, that the temporall Prince hath no power or authority ouer Clergie men, who are Å¿ubiect to him in temporalls, againÅ¿t the lawfull command of his Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tour, becauÅ¿e he hath no power to Å¿inne, it would likewiÅ¿e follow, that a Å¿uÅ¿pended BiÅ¿hop, or PrieÅ¿t, haue no power to giue orders, or to conÅ¿ecrate, becauÅ¿e they haue no power to Å¿inne; and a penitent hath no lawfull right, or power to Å¿ell, or giue away his goods againÅ¿t the lawfull command of his GhoÅ¿tly Father, becauÅ¿e he hath no power to Å¿inne; and a man hath no power, or right to giue money to a diÅ¿honeÅ¿t end, or to giue away his goods prodigally, and conÅ¿equently they Å¿hould be reÅ¿tored back againe, becauÅ¿e he hath no power to Å¿inne. 42 Thus you haue Å¿eene in what manner temporall thinges are Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall, temporall endes to Å¿pirituall endes, temporall power to the Å¿pirituall power, the temporall Å¿word to the Å¿pirituall Å¿word, the fleÅ¿h to the Å¿pirit, the Moone to the Sunne, and temporall Princes to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tors; and that from the Å¿ubiection and Å¿ubordination of the temporall power to the Å¿pirituall, no good argument can be brought to proue, that the Pope, by vertue of his Å¿pirituall power can diÅ¿poÅ¿e of temporalls, depoÅ¿e temporall Princes, or puniÅ¿h temporally by way of coercion, but onely that in order to Å¿pirituall good he can command temporalls, and puniÅ¿h temporally by way of command, but by way of coercion onely with Å¿pirituall, and not with temporall puniÅ¿hments. And by this which hath bene Å¿aide, the Reader may eaÅ¿ily vnderÅ¿tand the true Å¿enÅ¿e and meaning of a certaine propoÅ¿ition, which Card. Bellarmine in his Schulckenius doth often inculcate (as though there were Å¿ome great myÅ¿tery lye hidden therein) to proue the Popes power to depoÅ¿e temporall Princes, to wit, that a ChriÅ¿tian Prince is a child of the Church, and Å¿ubiect to the Pope, not onely as he is a ChriÅ¿tian man, but alÅ¿o as he is a ChriÅ¿tian Prince; and the Å¿ame he affirmeth of a ChriÅ¿tian â¢ awyer, of a ChriÅ¿tian Souldier, of a ChriÅ¿tian PhyÅ¿itian, and Å¿o of the reÅ¿t.

43 For all theÅ¿e three propoÅ¿itions, A ChriÅ¿tian Prince, as he is a ChriÅ¿tian Prince, is a child of the Church, and Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours: A ChriÅ¿tian Prince as he is a ChriÅ¿tian is a Child of the Church, and Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours: and a Prince as he is a ChriÅ¿tian, is a Childe of the Church and Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours; haue one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame Å¿enÅ¿e; and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e of a ChriÅ¿tian Lawier, of a ChriÅ¿tian Soldier, of a ChriÅ¿tian PhyÅ¿itian &c. For the true meaning of them all is, that ChriÅ¿tianitie, and not Regall authority, or the knowledge of lawe, warfare, or
PhyÅ¿icke, is the cauÅ¿e why a Prince, a Lawier, a Soldier, a PhyÅ¿itian, and all other men of what trade Å¿oeuer they be, are Children of the Church, and Å¿ubiect to Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours; and that therefore they are to be directed and inÅ¿tructed by Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours, not preciÅ¿ely in the rules of ciuill gouernment, in the rules of lawe, warfare, or PhyÅ¿icke, but onely in the rules and principles of ChriÅ¿tian doctrine, and how they ought to gouerne ciuilly, and vÅ¿e their knowledge and trades according to the rules and precepts of ChriÅ¿tian Religion: which if they refuÅ¿e to doe, they may be corrected and puniÅ¿hed by Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours, with Å¿pirituall or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall puniÅ¿hments.

44 But from hence it doth not follow, that either temporall power, the knowledge of the lawe, warfare, or phyÅ¿icke, are among ChriÅ¿tians per Å¿e Å¿ubiect to the Å¿pirituall power, but onely per accidens, as I haue often declared, and in thoÅ¿e thinges, which doe concerne or belong to ChriÅ¿tian Religion, or that Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours can by vertue of their Å¿pirituall power correct, or puniÅ¿h ChriÅ¿tian Princes, Lawiers, Soldiers, PhyÅ¿itians &c. by depriuing them by way of Å¿entence of their Regall authoritie, of their Å¿kill and knowledge in the lawes, in warfare, or PhyÅ¿icke, which they did not receiue from the Å¿pirituall power, but onely by depriuing them of the Sacraments, and Å¿uch like Å¿pirituall benifites, of which they are made partakers by being ChriÅ¿tians, and by meanes of the Å¿pirituall power and authority of Å¿pirituall PaÅ¿tours. And thus much concerning the vnion and Å¿ubiection of the temporall and Å¿pirituall power, and alÅ¿o of the Å¿econd part.

div.head: AN ADJOJNDER to the firÅ¿t and Å¿econd Part, wherein Widdringtons Interpretation of that ClauÅ¿e of the Oath, wherein the Doctrine (that Princes, who are excommunicated or depriued by the Pope, may bee depoÅ¿ed or murthered by their Subiects) is abiured as impious and hereticall, is proued to be Å¿ound, and Å¿ufficient, and is cleared from all abÅ¿urdity or contradiction, euen by Mr. FITZHERBERTS examples, and that it may without any Periury be Å¿worne by any CATHOLIKE.

PErceiuing, Courteous Reader, that this my AnÅ¿wer to Mr. Fitzherberts Reply doth ariÅ¿e to a greater bigneÅ¿Å¿e, then at the firÅ¿t I imagined: for that I am compelled not onely to anÅ¿wer him, but alÅ¿o D. adioyning, by way of an Appendix, for thy better Å¿atiÅ¿faction, the AnÅ¿wer which I made to Mr. Fitzherberts fourth Chapter, wherein hee excepteth againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e words of the Oath (as impious and hereticall Doctrine) for againÅ¿t no other clauÅ¿e of the Oath doth hee make any particular obiection, beÅ¿ides his generall diÅ¿courÅ¿e in fauour of the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of all temporalls. 2 FirÅ¿t therefore Mr. Fitzherbert in the beginning of his fourth Chapter, Å¿eemeth to take it very ill, for that I fall, Å¿aith he, vppon him very foule, charging h â¢ m with flat falÅ¿ity at the firÅ¿t word. But truely hee doth in this exaggerate the matter Å¿omwhat more then is needfull, as alÅ¿o in that he Å¿aith, that for a while I made my Å¿elfe merry with Fa. LeÅ¿Å¿ius. For beÅ¿ides that the word flat is added by himÅ¿elfe, I did neither cogge, Å¿coffe, gibe, or make my Å¿elfe merry with Fa. LeÅ¿Å¿ius: but after I had brought thoÅ¿e foure inÅ¿tances to confute Fa. LeÅ¿Å¿ius his antecedent propoÅ¿ition, whereon hee

And as for charging my AduerÅ¿ary with flat falÅ¿ity, my wordes were onely theÅ¿e: Thirdly it is falÅ¿e which this Author F. T. affirmeth, to wit, that the Doctrine concerning the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, is plainely abiured in â¢ his Oath, as impious and hereticall, for this doctrine onely is abiured in this Oath as impious and hereticall, that Princes being excommunicated or depriued by the Pope, may bee depoÅ¿ed or murthered by their Å¿ubiects or any other whatÅ¿oeuer: which poÅ¿ition, as I will declare beneath, hath this Å¿enÅ¿e, that it is in the free power of Subiects to depoÅ¿e, or (if they will) to murther their Prince, beeing excommunicated, or depriued by the Pope.

3 In the very firÅ¿t beginning I affirmed, and Mr. Fitzherbert in his firÅ¿t Chapter related my words, that the Å¿uppoÅ¿ition, which hee made, to wit, that the Popes power to excommunicate Princes is denyed in this Oath, is moÅ¿t falÅ¿e and then he took no exception againÅ¿t this word, moÅ¿t falÅ¿e: and now after he hath Å¿o often fallen very foule vpon mee, with charging mee with being abÅ¿urd, ridiculous, fooliÅ¿h, malicious, impudent, impious, with cogging, Å¿coffing gibing, heretike, and being no good Child of the Catholike Church, and vÅ¿ing many Å¿uch like Å¿landerous, and diÅ¿gracefull termes againÅ¿t mee, hee taketh it very ill for that I onely affirme his aÅ¿Å¿ertion to bee falÅ¿e, which word neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e is vÅ¿uall in Schooles among DiÅ¿puters and AnÅ¿werers, and is not taken for any diÅ¿gracefull tearme, being in Å¿enÅ¿e all one with vntrue, or I deny the aÅ¿Å¿ertion or poÅ¿ition. But becauÅ¿e I perceiue Mr. Fitzherberts patience cannot

4 But to the matter. Mr. Fitzherbert in his fourth Chapter endeauoreth to proue two things: the one that I haue falÅ¿ly charged him with affirming, that the Doctrine for the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, is manifeÅ¿tly abiured in the Oath, as impious and hereticall, which hee denyeth to haue affirmed, although hee granteth withall, â¢ hat it is true if hee had affirmed it. The Å¿econd is, that my interpretation of that clauÅ¿e of the Oath, wherein the aforeÅ¿aid Doctrine and PoÅ¿ition, That Princes being excommunicated or depriued by the Pope, may be depoÅ¿ed or murthered by their Subiects, is abiured as impious and hereticall, is abÅ¿urd according to my owne grounds.

5. As touching the firÅ¿t. Mr. Fitzherbert affirmeth, Cap. 4. nu. 1. that he Å¿aith nothing at all touching his owne opinion, whether the doctrine of depoÅ¿ing Princes be abiured in the Oath as impious and hereticall (and much leÅ¿Å¿e that it is manifestly abiured as I Å¿ay he doth) but he affirmeth onely, that the Oath is wholy repugnant to a Canon of the great Councell of Lateran by reaÅ¿on of two clauÅ¿es therein. Fourthly, it appeareth alÅ¿o hereby, and by all the premiÅ¿es, that this Oath of pretended allegiance is an vnlawfull Oath, and not to be taken by any ChriÅ¿tian man, Å¿eeing that it flatly contradicteth the Å¿aid Councell, and Canon, not onely becauÅ¿e it denieth that the Pope hath any power or authority to depoÅ¿e his MaieÅ¿tie,

And I do further Å¿weare, that from my hart I doe abhorre, deteÅ¿t, & abiure, as impious and heretical, this damnable doctrin, and poÅ¿ition, that princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed, which poÅ¿ition was by that Canon expreÅ¿ly ordained to be practiÅ¿ed in Å¿ome caÅ¿es, yea and executed by the Councells order vpon Reymond Earle of ToloÅ¿a. Thus Å¿ay I in my Suppliment.

6. Now I report
Nu. 3. me to the indifferent Reader, whether I affirme any more, then that theÅ¿e two clauÅ¿es of the Oath are flatly againÅ¿t the Councell of Lateran, becauÅ¿e the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes (which the Å¿aid Councell acknowledgeth and approueth by an expreÅ¿Å¿e Canon) is denied therein; and this is manifeÅ¿t as well by all my precedent diÅ¿courÅ¿e, as by that which followeth; for all that which I amply debated before, touching the Councell of Lateran, concerned onely the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes, without any one word whether the abiuration or deniall thereof be hereticall; and my concluÅ¿ion of the later clauÅ¿e confirmeth the Å¿ame: for I add immediately theÅ¿e words, which poÅ¿ition, (to wit, that Princes being excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed) was by that Canon expreÅ¿ly ordained to be practiÅ¿ed in Å¿ome caÅ¿es; yea and was executed by the Councels order, vpon Reymond Earle of ToloÅ¿a.

7. Whereby it appeareth,
Nu. 4. that whereas the clauÅ¿e mentioneth two thinges; the one the doctrine and poÅ¿ition, that Princes excommunicated, or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed; and the other, that the Å¿aid doctrine is abiured, as impious and hereticall; I treat onely of the former, and Å¿peake not one word of the later. So as my AduerÅ¿ary Widdrington charging me to haue falÅ¿ly affirmed, that the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes is manifeÅ¿tly abiured in this Oath, hath charged me falÅ¿ely, and therefore may take his imputation of falÅ¿ity to himÅ¿elfe. 8. But in truth I cannot but wonder, where Mr. Fitzherberts memory was, when he wrote theÅ¿e words, that he could not perceiue, that he himÅ¿elfe here Å¿aith as much as I affirmed him to Å¿ay: and therefore if he can finde no better a Å¿hift and euaÅ¿ion, then to deny with Å¿o bould a face that very Å¿ame thinge, which he himÅ¿elfe in this very place doth Å¿o plainly affirme, the vntruth, I dare not Å¿ay falÅ¿ity, wherewith I charged him, will Å¿till remaine with him, and will not be taken from him by me, beÅ¿ides the diÅ¿grace for a man of his faÅ¿hion, quality, and profeÅ¿Å¿ion, to deny Å¿o bouldly that he affirmeth that thing, which euery Child who vnderÅ¿tandeth EngliÅ¿h, may perceiue that he doth affirme. For marke his words. The Oath, Å¿aith he, bindeth the takers of it in expreÅ¿Å¿e words to Å¿weare thus: And I doe further Å¿weare, that I doe from my heart abhorre, deteÅ¿t, and abiure, as impious and hereticall, this damnable doctrine and poÅ¿ition, that Princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed. Now let any man iudge, whether he that affirmeth, that the Oath bindeth the takers of it in expreÅ¿Å¿e words to Å¿weare, that he doth abiure as impious and hereticall this doctrine, that Prince â¢ excommunicated or depriued by the Pope m y be depoÅ¿ed, doth not affirme, that the doctrine concerning the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes is plainely, manifeÅ¿tly, or in expreÅ¿Å¿e words abiured in this oath as impious and hereticall.

9. But obÅ¿erue how cunningly M. Fitzherbert, belike to returne the imputation of falÅ¿ity vpon mee would delude his Reader. Whereas the clauÅ¿e of the oath, Å¿aith he, mentioneth two things; the one the doctrine and poÅ¿ition, that Princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed; and the other, that the Å¿ai â¢ doctrine is abiured as impious and hereticall, (Loe here againe hee granteth as much, as I Å¿aid hee did affirme, to wit, that the doctrine, which holdeth that Princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed, is abiured in this oath as impious and hereticall)

10. Belike this man would make his Reader beleeue, that I did Å¿ay, that he had amply debated, treated, or made Å¿ome diÅ¿courÅ¿e of this point, and that he had endeauoured to proue, that the oath is vnlawfull, and againÅ¿t the Councell of Lateran, in regard it bindeth the takers of it to Å¿weare, that they doe from their heart abhorre, deteÅ¿t, and abiure as impious and hereticall this doctrine and poÅ¿ition, that Princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed; whereas I Å¿ay no Å¿uch thing, but onely that MaÅ¿ter Fitzherbert doth barely affirme, that the oath bindeth the takers to abiure, or, which is all one in Å¿enÅ¿e, that in this oath is abiured as impious and hereticall this doctrine, and categoricall propoÅ¿ition, ex parte praedicati, that Princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed. And thus much hee himÅ¿elfe, as you haue Å¿eene in this very place, doth twice affirm: which his aÅ¿Å¿ertion I Å¿aid is not true, for that it onely bindeth the takers to abiure a impious, and hereticall, this doctrine and hypotheticall propoÅ¿ition ex parte praedicati, that Princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed or murthered by their Å¿ubiects, or any other whatÅ¿oeuer, which hath a farre different Å¿enÅ¿e from the former, as I will Å¿hew beneath. And thus much for the firÅ¿t point. Now you Å¿hall Å¿ee how learnedly he proueth the Å¿econd.

11. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e I would not, Å¿aith he, Nu. 5. haue Widdrington
to thinke, that becauÅ¿e I deny, that I haue Å¿aid Å¿o in my Supplement, therefore I doe, or will deny, that it is Å¿o: for it is euident in that clauÅ¿e, that the taker of the oath abiureth this doctrine as impious and hereticall, to wit, that Princes excommunicated or depriued by the Pope may be depoÅ¿ed, or murthered by their Å¿ubiects, or any other, whereby not onely the Popes power to depoÅ¿e Princes is denyed, but alÅ¿o the doctrine thereof is abiured as impious and hereticall: And this, I Å¿ay, is euident, notwithÅ¿tanding the friuolous euaÅ¿ion, which my AduerÅ¿ary Widdrington Å¿eketh by his extrauagant interpretation of that clauÅ¿e, when hee Å¿aith, as you haue heard, that the Å¿enÅ¿e and meaning thereof is no other, but that it is hereticall to affirme it to be in the free power of Å¿ubiects or any other to depoÅ¿e, or (if they liÅ¿t) to kill Princes that are excommunicated or depriued by the Pope.

So that albeit there be mention alÅ¿o of the depoÅ¿ition of Princes (as that they may be depoÅ¿ed or murthered) yet the doctrine of depoÅ¿ition is not abiured in that clauÅ¿e as hereticall, except it be ioyned with the murther of them; in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that a man may freely chooÅ¿e whether he will depoÅ¿e, or murther them.

13. But that the Reader may more fully vnderÅ¿tand, whether MaÅ¿ter Fitzherberts Reply be a meere Å¿hift, or my anÅ¿were an abÅ¿urd friuolous, and extrauagant euaÅ¿ion, and contention de lana caprina (Å¿uch foule termes, and farre worÅ¿e it is not foule for him to vÅ¿e againÅ¿t mee, and yet if I doe onely Å¿ay, that hee affirmeth that which is falÅ¿e, or not true, I fall very foule vpon him) I will Å¿et downe entirely, what I anÅ¿wered in my Theologicall

(And I do further Å¿weare, that I do from my hart abhorre, deteÅ¿t and abiure, as impiuos and hereticall, this damnable doctrine and poÅ¿ition, That Princes which be excommuicated or depriued by the Pope, may be depoÅ¿ed or murthered by their Å¿ubiects, or any other whatÅ¿oeuer) cannot be taken without periurie: And this was his argument.

14. WhenÅ¿oeuer an affirmatiue propoÅ¿ition is hereticall, of neceÅ¿Å¿ity it muÅ¿t be either against faith, and conÅ¿equently againÅ¿t the expreÅ¿Å¿e word of God, or elÅ¿e the contradictorie negatiue muÅ¿t be a poÅ¿ition of faith, and contained in the expreÅ¿Å¿e word of God.
